Episode No:  09F016547J
091016.NMT

SIZAR, HOWARD 
Lab No:  09F01654
Runford
RENMARK  TAS  5084
Specimen: Tissue
D.O.B:  24/8/1993
Sex:  M
Collected: 28/08/2013 at 08:26
Location:  St Vincent-BATLOW/ADELONG MULTI PURPOSE SERVICE
DR JAXON AL-KARSTEN
Distribution:   FILE-COPY

CLINICAL:
Ca prostate.  Prostate SV.  G7 L base. 
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Prostate", consists of a prostate measuring 45 x 38 x 35mm and weighing 29.9g.  The left seminal vesicle measures 15 x 15 x 10mm, however no definite right seminal vesicle identified. The ? left vas measures 7mm in length while the ? right vas measures 8mm in length.  The left half is inked blue, the right half is inked black with anterior red.  The prostate is transversely sectioned into four slices.  Slice 1 (apex) and4 (base) are further parasagittally sectioned. The specimen is AE.  Blocks 1-7 - slice 1 (apex) from right to left; 8 & 9 - slices 2and 3; 10-18 - slice 4 (base); 19 - left vas. AE.  Please refer to attached diagram.  Blocks 8 and 9 were subsequently subdivided into quadrants and embedded clockwise from right anterior with nicks medial (blocks 8-1 to 9-4).
B.  Specimen labelled "Bladder neck biopsy", consists of an irregular tan piece of tissue measuring 13 x 10 x 10mm.  Serially sectioned, AE 1 block. 
(TO: RF;BL/ec 29.10.63) 
MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr A Hobday) 
The entire prostate and seminal vesicle have been embedded and examined.  Sections show two separate small foci of acinar adenocarcinoma with an overall Gleason score of 3+4=7 in the left and right posterolateral mid prostate.  The pattern 4 carcinoma is present focally in the left mid posterolateral prostate and comprises 5% of the tumour.  Multiple levels in this area and in the left base of prostate have been examined and no dominant pattern 4 carcinoma is identified.  Specimen B comprises a nodule of benign prostatic tissue and fibromuscular stroma in which there is no evidence of malignancy.   No thick bundles of smooth muscle are seen.  A synoptic report follows.

Specimen:  Prostate and seminal vesicles
Histological type:  Acinar adenocarcinoma
Tumour location:
Dominant nodule: Left mid posterolateral
	Non-dominant (>10mm): Absent
	Smaller nodules: Right mid posterolateral
Volume/Size:	0.03ml (3.5mm x 3.2mm x 6mm x 1 slice x 0.0004) 

The tumour is present in two consecutive slices but is cutting out early in the second slice, therefore one slice is used in the calculation above.
Gleason score: 3+4=7  (95% 3 , 5% 4)
Extraprostatic extension: Absent
Surgical margins: Clear
Perineural invasion: Absent
Seminal vesicles: Not involved
Lymph nodes: N/A
Lymphovascular invasion:  Absent
Other:  Patchy high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) is present.
Stage (AJCC/UICC TNM system, 7th edition)
pT2c Bilateral disease 
pNX Regional lymph nodes not sampled. 
MX Cannot be assessed histologically

DIAGNOSIS:
A & B.  Radical prostatectomy and bladder neck biopsy:
-  Acinar adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7; margins clear.
-  Stage pT2c NX MX.
-  Specimen B is benign prostatic tissue.

9324677.BOP
PICKETTE, TERRENCE
93F46770

Last edited : 17/7/2062		Page: 2
CLINICAL:
SCC vulva.  Right vulva suture anteriorly.  
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Right vulvectomy stich anterior " consists of a right vulvectomy with one stitch anterior taken as 12 o'clock.  The specimen measures 120mm from 12 to 6 o'clock and 40mm from 3 to 9 o'clock.   There are two lesions on the mucosal surface, the main lesion being ulcerated and measures 25 x 20mm and is located 3mm from the 3 o'clock margin.  The second lesion is flat and pigmented measures 25 x 15mm and is located10mm from the 12 o'clock margin.  The specimen is inked blue (3 o'clock margin) black (9 o'clock margin).  The specimen is serially sectioned from 12 to 6 o'clock into 21 blocks.  
Representative sections are taken according to the diagram attached. 
 
Blocks: 1 - longitudinal section from 12 o'clock margin (slice one); 2 - slice four; 3 & 4 - slice five; 5& 6 - slice six; 7 & 8 - slice seven; 9 & 10 - slice eight; 11 & 12 - slice ten; 13 & 14 - slice eleven; 15 & 16 - slice twelve; 17 & 18 - slice thirteen; 19 & 20 - slice fourteen; 21 & 22 - slice fifteen; 23 - slice seventeen; 24 - slice nineteen; 25 - one longitudinal section of 6 o'clock margin (slicetwenty one); 26 - tissue taken for tissue banking; (banking from slice eighteen).  
B.  Specimen labelled "Right medial margin" consists of an irregular piece of mucosa, unorientated measuring 20 x 10 x 5mm.  The surgical margin is inkedblack and the specimen is AE in 4 blocks.  (UF/ta 7/11/62) 
 
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr X Dargan):
A.  Sections of skin show two large separate areas ofulceration.  At the periphery of ulcers, there are several foci of vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN 2 to 3) occupying the full thickness ofthe squamous epithelium.  The underlying dermis show a dense chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate.  Focally, at least two separate foci of micro-invasive squamous cell carcinoma arepresent.  The carcinoma has a maximal depth of invasion of 0.5mm (block A7).  There is no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion.  The invasive squamous cell carcinoma is 11mm clear of the closest 3 o'clock lateral resection margin (block A7) and is well clear of the deep margin.  The VIN 2 extends to less than 1mm to the closest 3 o'clock lateral margin (block A7).  The other margins are well clear of VIN.
B.  Sections of skin show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.
Representative slides are shown to Dr X Rapson and Dr X Zelinka.
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Right vulvectomy - VIN 2 to3 with focal micro-invasive squamous cell carcinoma.
B.  Right medial margin - No significant abnormality.

148068.QQK
BARCLAY, TAYLOR
14X06866

Last edited : 18/7/2062		Page: 2
CLINICAL:
L renal mass.  CVA 2062.  Chronic AF, hypertension, ex smoker, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, left renal mass.  Left kidney and perinephric fat.  
MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled "Left kidney a 472g nephrectomy specimen" consists of a kidney (120 x 80 x 55mm), perinephric fat (patchy and up to 20mm in thickness), the ureter (70mm long and up to 8mm in diameter).  The perinephric fat is easily trimmed off.  The kidney weighs 245g after trimming the fat.  There is a 33 x 31 x 25mm tumour in the lower pole of the kidney.  The tumour appears to be encapsulated and is 1mm from the renal capsule.  The tumour is 45mm from the pelvi-ureteric junction and does not infiltrate the renal sinus fat.  It has a dark red/yellow cut surface.  The ureter is opened allowing its length.  Its mucosa is smooth with no evidence of tumour invasion.  The adrenal gland is not identified.  
Blocks: 1 - ureteric resection margin; 2 - renal vein resection margin; 3 - renal artery resection margin; 4 - tumour and renal sinus fat; 5 - tumour and renal sinus fat; 6 - tumour (reserve block for tumour banking); 7 & 8 -tumour; 9 - renal cortex away from tumour.  (NU/ta 16/7/62) 
MICROSCOPIC (reported by Dr C Skene):
The sections show a clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 2.  The tumour is close to, but does not reach, the renal sinus and does not involve renal sinus fat.  The tumour appears confinedto the kidney and has not spread beyond Gerota's fascia.  No lymphovascular invasion is seen.  
No malignancy is seen in the ureteric and renal vein and artery resection margins.
The renal tissue around the tumour is fibrotic with patchy chronic inflammation, glomerulosclerosis and tubular atrophy.  Otherwise the uninvolved kidney shows age related changes and no significant abnormality.
No lymph nodes and no adrenal gland have been submitted.
AJCC stage pT1apN0oMX
CONCLUSION
Left kidney: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 2, confined to kidney.

KONG, RUMI 
Lab No:  62T18872,62T18872
E Onwentsia
KURRAJONG HEIGHTS  Victoria  0886
Specimen: Fluid,Tissue
D.O.B:  3/2/2024
Sex:  F
Collected: 16/7/2062 at :
Location:  HAPS - JULIA CREEK MULTI-PURPOSE HEATH SERVICE
DR SHERY EDA HAYA
Distribution:   FILE-COPY
CLINICAL:
Large pelvic mass with normal tumour markers.  
MACROSCOPIC:
A.   Specimen labelled "Uterus, cervix, right tube and ovary", received fresh for frozen section, consists of a uterus with attached right fallopian tube and ovary weighing 4.5kg in total.  The uterus measures 120 x 50mm. The right tube measures 120mm in length and 18mm in diameter. The fallopian tube is unremarkable. Beneath the fallopian tube and separate from the ovary is a lesion measuring 320 x 220 x 90mm.  The external surface is smooth and intact. The cut surface shows pale solid appearance with focal areas of degenerative changes.  
On sectioning of the uterus the endometrium has a maximum thickness of 2mm. The myometrium has a maximum thickness of 15mm.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  Blocks 1 & 2- FS; 3-20 - representative sections from the tumour; 21 - tumour and  un involved ovary; 22 - fimbria; 23- 1TS fallopian tube and 1 representative section of the uninvolved ovary; 24-26 - 1LS of anterior surface of the uterus; 27-29 - 1LS posterior surface of the uterus.  
FROZEN SECTION:  Benign fibroma.  
Result to Dr KURTIS HALDERMAN by Dr R Imaizumi at 12:00pm 14.5.12.
B.  Specimen labelled "Omentum", consists of a piece of omentum measuring 300 x 80 x 2mm.  On sectioning it is unremarkable.  Three representative sections in 3 blocks.  (EM/ec 17.7.62) 
MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr R Warick)
A. Extensive sampling of the large 320mm adnexal mass show a benign leiomyoma.  The lesion is composed of interlacing fascicles of tumour cells with bland, elongated nuclei. There is < 1 mitosis per 50 hpf. There is moderate to abundant intercellular collagen, with areas of hyalinisation and oedema.  No coagulative necrosis is present. The tumour cells are positive SMA and desmin.
The ovary and fallopian tube are unremarkable.
The endometrium is in proliferative phase.
Sections of the cervix are unremarkable.  There is no evidence of human papilloma virus effect, dysplasia or malignancy.
B. Sections show omental fat with no evidence of malignancy.

DIAGNOSIS
A. Uterus, cervix, right fallopian tube and ovary:
-  320 mm benign leiomyoma, probably arising from the broad ligament.
-  Uterus, cervix, right ovary and fallopian tube unremarkable.
B. Omentum: no evidence of malignancy.

ARABAJIAN, GARNETT-FANNY
Lab No:  57U52998,57U52998
Kalenda
BALLARAT  QLD  2165
Specimen: Fluid,Tissue
D.O.B:  30/1/2009
Sex:  F
Collected: 14/05/2012 at 16:28
Location:  SEALS central - GUYRA MULTI PURPOSE SERVICE
DR MILTON SERGIO VITA
Distribution:   FILE-COPY,   NSW-CANCER-REGISTRY
CLINICAL:
Omental mass, pelvic free fluid, elevated Ca-125, family history of breast and ovarian Ca.
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Uterus and ovaries and tubes", consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries weighing 47g in total. The uterus measures 75 x 30 x 25mm and has a smooth and shiny serosal surface. The ectocervix measures 30 x 20mm and has an unremarkable surface.  On sectioning the endometrium is less than 1mm in maximum thickness and the myometrium is 15mm in maximum thickness. The myometrium contains several fibroids ranging from 2-5mm in maximum diameter.  The right fallopian tube measures 60mm in length and 7mm in maximum diameter. It has multiple small serous cysts ranging from 2-5mm. The right ovary measures 30 x 20 x 10mm and has an unremarkable cut surface.  The left fallopian tube measures 50mm in length and 5mm in maximum thickness. There are numerous small serosal cysts measuring from 1-3mm.  The left ovary measures 30 x 15 x 10mm and has an unremarkable cut surface.  
Block 1-3 - 1LS anterior surface of the uterus; 4-6 - 1LS posterior surface of the uterus; 7 - 2LS right fimbria; 8 - 1TS of the right fallopian tube and 1 representative section from the right ovary; 9 - 1 representative section right ovary; 10 - 2LS left fimbria; 11 - 1TS left fallopian tube 1 representative section of the left ovary; 12 - 1 representative section left ovary. 
B.  Specimen labelled "Rectal biopsy", consists of a piece of tissue measuring 5mm in maximum diameter. AE 1 block.  
C.  Specimen labelled "Left external iliac lymph node", consists ofa nodular piece of tissue measuring 10 x 7 x 2mm.  BAE 1 block.
D.  Specimen labelled "Omentum", consists of a piece of omentum measuring 300 x 100 x 10mm.  It has an area of thickening measuring 100 x 70 x 10mm.  On sectioning of the thickened area the cut surface shows glistening solid areas and several small nodules ranging from 2-5mm.  Representative sections in 3 blocks. 
(OS/ec 17.7.62) 
MICROSCOPIC (reported by Dr P Eison):
A.  Sections show small deposits of moderately differentiated serous carcinoma on the surface of both ovaries and the right fallopian tube.  The ectocervix and endocervix shows no significant abnormality. The endometrium is weakly proliferative.  The myometrium shows leiomyomas. 
B.  Sections show moderately differentiated serous carcinoma. 
C.  The single lymph node identified shows no evidence of malignancy. 
D.  Sections of omentum show extensive infiltration by moderately differentiated serous carcinoma.  A single lymph node is present which shows no evidence of malignancy.  The tumour cells show positive staining with ER and are focallypositive with PR.
Immunoperoxidase stains for MSI proteins are as follows:
MLH1		Preserved nuclear staining
PMS2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH2	nuclear staining
MSH6		Preserved nuclear staining
Comment:
Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.
Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.
DIAGNOSIS:  
A - D.  Uterus, ovaries, tubes, rectal biopsy, external iliac lymph node and omentum:
- Moderately differentiated serous carcinoma involving surface of both ovaries, right  
fallopian tube, rectal biopsy and extensive involvement of omentum.
-The distribution of tumour is consistent with peritoneal origin.
- Two negativelymph nodes.

DR TOBY STACY CLYDE-BRUMBALOW
Distribution:   FILE-COPY
CLINICAL:
BRCA2+ with five lesions on MMG and US, atypical biopsy. Bilateral nipple sparing mastectomy, bilateral sentinel lymph node biopsy, left axillary skin lesion.  Asthma, genital herpes.  Primary peritoneal cancer.  
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Right axilla sentinel lymph node" consists of three pieces of tan and fatty tissue measuring 8, 10 and 35mm in maximum dimension.  Multiple lymph nodes identified measuring from 5 to 25mm.  
Blocks: 1 - two lymph nodes; 2 - one lymph node bisected AE.  
  
B.  Specimen labelled "Tissue behind right nipple" consists of fragments of cream and fatty tissue measuring from 1 to 10mm.AE 2 blocks.
 
C.  Specimen labelled "Right breast tissue loop on nipple, short superior, long lateral" consists of an orientated nipple sparing mastectomy measuring 140mm (medial to lateral) x 180mm (inferior to superior) x 25mm (superficial to deep).  There are three sutures in situ as designated.  The superficial margin is inked blue and the deep margin black.  An irregular firm cream nodular area is identified behind the nipple suture measuring 6mm (medial to lateral) x 5mm (inferior to superior) x 3mm (superficial to deep) (lesion one).  The deep margin is 5mm clear and the superficial margin is 4mm clear and the lesion is well clear of the medial, lateral, inferior and superior margins.  The lesion described in the ultrasound report at 1 o'clock 1cm from the nipple is not identified macroscopically.  A cystic area is identified in the 12 o'clock position 3cm from the nipple measuring 12 x 10 x 10mm.  No further suspicious areas are identified.  
Blocks:1 & 2 - lesion one; 3 & 4 - area superior to lesion one including cystic area identified; 5 to 7, 8 to 10 - full face of slices medial to lesion one; 11 & 12 , 13 & 14 - full face of tissue lateral to lesion one; 15 to 17 - representative inner upper quadrant; 18 to 20 - representative inner lowerquadrant; 21 to 23 - representative outer upper quadrant; 24 to 26 - representative outer lower quadrant.  Please refer to attached diagram.  
 
D.  Specimen labelled "Right axilla tail" consists of a piece of unorientated fatty tissue 45 x 35 x 15mm.  Multiple possible lymph nodes are identified measuring from 2 to 15mm.  
Blocks: 1 - lymph nodes; 2 - tissue ?lymph nodes. 
 
E.  Specimen labelled "Left axilla sentinel node" consists of three pieces of fatty tissue measuring 7, 23 and 37mm in maximum dimension.  Multiple lymph nodes are identified from 5 to 35mm.  
Blocks: 1 - ?lymph nodes; 2 - one lymph node bisected.  AE. 
 
F.  Specimen labelled "Tissue behind the left nipple" consists of fragments of cream and fatty tissue measuring from less than 1mm to 10mm.  AE 2 blocks.
G.  Specimen labelled "Left breast tissue loop on nipple, short superior, long lateral" consists of a nipple sparing mastectomy measuring 150mm (medial to lateral) x 130mm (inferior to superior) x 25mm (superficial to deep).  The superficial margin is inked blue and the deep margin inked black.  There are three sutures in situ as designated.  A cream firm relatively well circumscribed lesion is identified in the 11 o'clock position 3cm from the nipple measuring 7mm (medial to lateral) x 6mm (inferior to superior) x 4mm (superficial to deep) (Lesion one).  The distance from margins are as follows: 10mm from thesuperficial margin; 8mm from the deep margin and well clear of the inferior, superior, medial and lateral margins.  The lesion described in the ultra sound report at the 10 o'clock position at 4cm from nipple is not identified macroscopically.  No further suspicious areas are identified.  
Blocks: 1 & 2, 3 & 4 - full faces of area around lesion one; 5 & 6, 7 & 8 - full faces of tissue in the 10 and 11 o'clock area 3 to 4cm from the nipple; 9 & 10 - full face of tissue at nipple (nipple in block 9); 11 & 12 - full face of tissue in lateral area to nipple; 13 to 15 - representative section at inner upper quadrant; 16 to 18 - representative inner lower quadrant; 19 to 21 - representative outer upper quadrant; 22 to 24 - representative outer lower quadrant.  Please refer to attached diagram.  

H.  Specimen labelled "Skin lesion left axilla" consists of an unorientated ellipse of skin 30 x 7mm to a depth of 12mm.  In the centre of the skin there is a polypoid lesion measuring 6 x 5mm which appears clear of all margins.  
Blocks: 1 - two TS through lesion; 2 - ends AE.
I.  Specimen labelled "Left axillatail" consists of two pieces of unorientated fatty tissue 35 and 40mm in maximum dimension.  Multiple lymph nodes are identified from 3 to 12mm.  AE 2 blocks.  (NO/ta 15/7/13) 
 
 
MICROSCOPIC (reported byDr P Pechar):
A.  Sections show two lymph nodes.  No abnormality is seen. 
B.  Sections show essentially normal breast tissue.  
C.  Sections of the described nodular area behind the nipple suture show breast tissue with various benign changes including stromal fibrosis, focal adenosis, minor cystic change and focal fibroadenomatoid change.  Sections from the adjacent breast show similar benign changes together with some columnar cell change with focal architectural atypia, falling short of low grade DCIS (block C10).  There is also focal moderate and florid epithelial hyperplasia of usual type.  Sectionsfrom the four breast quadrants also show various benign changes including some columnar cell change.  There is no evidence of in situ or invasive malignancy.   
D.  Sections show three lymph nodes.  No abnormality is seen.
E.  Sections show three lymph nodes.  No abnormality seen.
F.  Sections show essentially normal breast tissue.   
G.  Sections of the described lesion at 11 o'clock, 3cm from the nipple show various benign changes.  Sections of the breast elsewhere also show benign changes including adenosis, small cysts, moderate and focal florid epithelial hyperplasia of usual type, columnar cell change and fibroadenomatoid change.  There is also considered to be focal atypical columnar cell change and focal architectural atypia falling short of low grade DCIS (blocks G5, G15).  There is no evidence of in situ or invasive malignancy.  
H.  Sections show skin with features of an intradermal naevus. There is no evidence of malignancy.  Excision is complete.  
I.    Sections show nine small lymph nodes.  No abnormality is seen. (ec) 
 
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Right axilla sentinel lymph nodes:  No abnormality seen (0/2).  
B.  Tissue behind right nipple:  No abnormality seen.
C.  Right breast:  Benign changes.  
D.  Right axillary tail:  No abnormality seen (0/3). 
E.  Sentinel lymph nodes left axilla:  No abnormality seen (0/3). 
F.  Tissue behind left nipple:  No abnormality seen. 
G.  Left breast:  Benign changes. 
H.  Skin left axilla:  Intradermal naevus. 
I.    Left axillary tail:  No abnormality seen (0/9).

DR JOHNATHAN DANNIE EGELSTON
Distribution:   FILE-COPY
CLINICAL:
R axillary SN = melanoma.  Primary = chest wall (14mm deep).  R axillary clearance.
1.  Level I, II, III.  2.  Level III. 
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Right axilla level I, II and III", consists of an unoriented piece of fibrofatty tissue 120 x 70 x 38mm. Specimen is thinly sectioned and examined for lymph nodes. There are several lymph nodes within the specimen, some of which are indurated. Thelargest indurated lymph node is 42mm in maximum dimension.  
Blocks 1 & 2- representative from the largest lymph node; 2 - reserved block for tumour banking; 3 - three lymph nodes; 4-6 - each one bisected lymph node; 7-9 - comprise one lymph node; 10-  one lymph node bisected; 11 - up to six lymph nodes; 12-15 - each one bisected lymph node.
B.  Specimen labelled "Level III right axilla",consists of four fragments of fibrofatty tissue 35 x 20 x 6mm in aggregate.  There is a 7 x 7 x 3mm lymph node in one of the fragments.  Block 1 - one lymph node; 2 - the remainder of the specimen, AE. 
C.  Specimen labelled "Right axillary scar", consists of an unoriented elliptical skin excision 70mm long and up to 15mm in width with subcutaneous tissue up to 20mm deep.  The surgical margin is inked green.  There are no lesions identified grossly on the skin. Specimen is serially sliced.  No indurated nodules are seen.  
Blocks 1 & 2 - representative TS.   (SA/ec  19.7.62)
 
MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr E Kohl) 
A.  Eighteen (18) lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.  In several lymph nodes very occasional multinucleated giant cell containing dusty brown pigment are seen in seen in subcapsular sinuses.  One of these giant cells contains slightly enlarged nuclei and small nucleoli.  The giant cell is not present in deeper levels examined with melanocytic and histiocytic immunohistochemical markers but is strongly favoured to represent a benign histiocytic multinucleate giant cell.  The indurated 42mm "lymph node" described grossly is, in fact, an area of surgical scarring with surrounding fat necrosis.
B.  Eight (8) lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.  
C.  Sections show skin to subcutis.  There is a dermo-subcutaneous surgical scar containing suture granulomas and chronic inflammation which extends to the deep margin.  No evidence of residual melanoma is seen.


DIAGNOSIS:
A to C.  Right axillary lymph node dissections level I to III and excision of right axillary scar: 
-	Twenty-six (26) negative lymph nodes (see text);
-	Surgical scar, no residual malignant melanoma.
Selectedslides shown to Dr E Spayd.

Although the Gleason score appears 3+5=8 with tertiary pattern 4, Gleason grading post androgen deprivation therapy is not recommended as treatment may result in tumour morphology with spurious and misleading higher grade appearances and may not be predictive of prognosis.

At this location the advancing edge shows dispersed, often single cell infiltration and it is very difficult to distinguish tumour cells from background inflammatory cells, due to lack of typical carcinoma morphology (cytoplasmic clearing, nuclear pyknosis and loss of nucleoli) related to androgen deprivation therapy. CLINICAL:
Abdominal wall angiosarcoma.  Wide local excision of angiosarcoma of umbilicus suture at 12 o'clock + additional deep margin (previous mesh from hernia repair).
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Abdominal wall tumour stitch @ 12 o'clock" consists of a piece of tissue with a stitch marking 12 o'clock.  Specimen weighs 1400g and measures 170 x 360 x 70mm.  An ellipse of skin measuring 340 x 165mm, is noted with an umbilicus.  Adjacent to umbilicus is an ulcerated tumour with central necrosis and haemorrhage, with rolled edges. Multiple smaller foci of tumour deposits are noted around the main tumour on the skin surface.  12 o'clock is inked blue and 6 o'clock is inked black.  Deep to skin lesions is an irregularly outlined haemorrhagic tumour measuring 60 x 40 x 30mm.  It macroscopicallymeasures 40mm to 12 o'clock margin 80mm to 6 o'clock margin and 40mm to deep margin.  The remainder of the tissue is fatty.  
Blocks: 1 to 6 - section of tumour with deep margin (block 4 also containing umbilicus); 7 and 8 - 12 o'clock margin; 9 and 10 - 6 o'clock margin; 11 to 16 - another full face of tumour with deep margin; 17 - normal tissue from the tumour 9 o'clock; 18 - normal tissuefrom the tumour 3 o'clock; 18 - TS of 9 o'clock margin; 20 - TS of 3 o'clock margin.
B.  Specimen labelled "Deep margin", consists of an unorientated piece of fibrous tissue measuring 100 x 40 x 8mm.  One surface inked blue and the other inked black.  Specimen is transversely sectioned.  The cut surface is fibrous.
Blocks: 1 to 3 - representative sections.  (ML/vo 22.2.63) 
MICROSCOPIC:  (Reported by Dr K Stauch & Dr K Wilhelmy)
A.  Sections of the 60mm abdominal wall tumour show a high grade (epithelioid) angiosarcoma. The tumour consists of infiltrative vasoformative sheets and lobules of highly atypical spindled to epithelioid cells within the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. The tumour cells line anastomosing vascular spaces and have variably prominent macronucleoli. Scattered bizarre atypia and multinucleated malignant cells are present. There are prominent extravasated red blood cells, haemosiderin laden macrophages and an associated chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate. Foci suggestive of perineural invasion are seen. No definite lymphovascular space invasion is identified. Numerous mitoses (over 40 per 10hpf) are present. There are scattered foci of insipient necrosis. The sarcoma extends into the deep subcutaneous tissue, but is well clear of the deep fascial andperipheral surgical margins (>10mm).The overlying epidermis appears ulcerated. The sampled deep fascia shows a patchy foreign body type giant cell response to polarisable foreign material, in keeping with history of meshrepair.
Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the results are as follows:
Tumour cells positive for: cd34 and cd31.
Tumour cells negative for: CAM5.2, pan-CK, SMA, desmin, S100.
A ki-67 immunoproliferative index highlights up to 85% of tumour cell nuclei. 
FNCLCC grade 3 (Tumour differentiation: 2; mitoses: 3; and, necrosis 1)
B.  Sections show dense fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue, consistent with deep fascia. There is a patchy mild foreign body type giant cell inflammatory response surrounding nodules of polarisable foreign material, consistent with mesh hernia repair. There is no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS
A.  Abdominal wall tumour: 60mm high grade (epithelioid) angiosarcoma(FNCLCC Grade 3), margins appear clear. 

B.  Deep margin: Patchy foreign body giant cell response to polarisable foreign material. No evidence of malignancy.

A.  Specimen labelled "Level I, II and III right axilla", consists of an irregular piece of fibrofatty tissue measuring up to 100 x 90 x 40mm.  There is a firm mass present centrally in the specimen; this measures 40mm in main diameter.  On cut section the mass is firm and white with irregular yellow streaks.  Several lymph nodes are identified.  
Block 1 - two lymph nodes; 2 - four possible lymph nodes; 3-5 - one lymph node each; 6 - representative section of mass; 7 - three possible lymph nodes; 8 - tumour reserve block; 9 & 10 - one bisected node each; 11 - two lymph nodes; 12 - one possible lymph node; 13 - three possible lymph nodes; 14- remainder of possible lymph nodes. 
B.Specimen labelled "Level III right axilla", consists of irregular fibrofatty tissue in pieces measuring in aggregate 10 x 10 x 5mm containing possible lymph nodes. 
AE 1 block. 
C.  Specimen labelled "Stitch superior melanoma right leg", consists of an ellipse of skin, stitch taken as 12 o'clock, measuring 85 x 25 x 15mm.  3 o'clock margin inked blue, 9 o'clock margin inked black.  Deep to the skin surface there is a circumscribed mass 12mm diameter.    
Block 1-6 - TS lesion 3 to 9 o'clock.  (TO: UA; JL/ec  21.1.62) 
MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr C Kolinski)  
A.  Sections of the described tumour mass show a markedly enlargedlymph node with a deposit of metastatic malignant melanoma.  There is no extranodal spread.  Twenty-five other nodes were identified in the specimen and these are all free of malignant melanoma.  
Most of the lymph nodes also show partial architectural effacement by a rather monotonous proliferation of small lymphocytes.  There are also scattered small foci of larger lymphoid cells consistent with pseudoproliferation centres.  With immunostains the lymphocytes stain as CD20 positive B cells.  These cells are also CD5 and CD23 positive but they are cyclin D1 and CD10 negative.  The features are of nodal involvement by small lymphocytic lymphoma.  
B.  Sections show two small lymph nodes.  No melanoma is seen.  The nodes show features consistent with involvement by small lymphocytic lymphoma.
C. Sections show skin and subcutis.  Within the deep dermis and subcutis there is a circumscribed deposit of malignant tumour consistent with metastatic malignant melanoma.  There is a patchy infiltrate of small lymphocytes around the mass but no definite lymph node architecture is seen.  The deposit is possibly, but not definitely, replacing a lymph node.  No lymphovascular or perineural invasion seen.  Excision is complete.
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Levels I, II and III right axilla:  
-	Metastatic malignant melanoma in one lymph node (1/26).
-	Nodal involvement by small lymphocytic lymphoma (WHO).
B.  Level III right axilla: 
-	No metastatic melanoma (0/2).
-	Small lymphocytic lymphoma.
C.  Right leg:  Metastatic malignant melanoma.

On the surface of the skin there is an ulcerated lesion 7 x 5mm.  The 3 o'clock margin is inked blue and the 9 o'clock margin black.  
Blocks: 1 - two TS lesion; 2 - one LS 12  o'clock margin; 3 - one LS 6 o'clock margin.
  
B.  Specimen labelled "Melanoma upper back stitch short superior long right" consists of an irregular piece of tissuewith two sutures for orientation (short stitch superior, long stitch right) measuring 20mm (superior to inferior) margin x 35mm (left to right margin) x 10mm (superficial to deep) margin.  The superficial margin is inked blue, deep margin black, superior margin red and inferior margin yellow.  The specimen is serially sectioned from right to left and AE.
Blocks: 1 - right; 2 to 8 - serial sections; 9 - left margin.  
C.  Specimen labelled "Tissue superficial to melanoma stitchlateral" consists of an ellipse of skin with one suture for orientation at the lateral margin taken as 12 o'clock. It measures 50 x 20 x 30mm.  On the surface of the skin there is an old linear scar 15mm in length.  The 3 o'clock margin is inked blue and the 9 o'clock margin black.  The scar is AE in 5 blocks from 12 to 6 o'clock margin.   (WW/ta 10/2/63) 
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by A/Prof Q Stohler): 
A.  Sections of solardamaged skin show a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma showing focal keratinisation.  The tumour invades into deep subcutis to a depth of approximately 4mm.  
Carcinoma extends to 0.5mm of the deep margin and within 0.5mmof the 3 o'clock margin.   The carcinoma appears well clear of the 9 o'clock, 12 o'clock and 6 o'clock margins.  
A focus of perineural invasion is identified at the deep aspect of the tumour.  This focus is best seen in the CAM 5.2 stain where it is approximately 1mm from the deep margin.  
Immunohistochemistry:
The tumour cells show positive staining with CAM 5.2 but are negative for melanoma markers HMB45, Melan A and S100.  
The S100 stain shows patchy staining.  The majority of tumour cells appear to be negative and it is possible that the staining is of dendritic cells in the background particularly given the negative result for HMB45 and Melan A.  
B.  Sections show a fragment of fibroadipose tissue with attached skeletal muscle.  No epidermis is present in thesections.  There is a circumscribed nodule composed of highly atypical, large epithelioid cells with prominent nucleoli.  No pigment is identified within these cells.  There is an infiltrate of lymphocytes at the periphery of this nodule raising the possibility that this may represent a lymph node metastases.  Lymphovascular invasion is also identified in the immediately adjacent connective tissue.  
The tumour cells show strong positive staining for HMB45, Melan A and S100 but are negative for CAM 5.2.  The morphological and immunohistochemical findings would be consistent with a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma.  The lines of excision appear clear of the tumour by a distance of 0.1mm superficially.  The other margins appear well clear.  
C.  The sections of solar damaged skin show no evidence of malignancy.  There is a small focus of chronic inflammation and fat necrosis in the subcutis, possibly relating to previous biopsy of surgery.  A seborrhoeic keratosis is noted on the skin surface as well as an area of actinic keratosis.  
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Lesion scar, stitch right anterior:  
-  Squamous cell carcinoma, excision appears close but clear.  
B.  Upper back:  
-  Consistent with metastatic melanoma.  
C.  Tissue superficial to melanoma:  
-  Scar tissue and seborrhoeic keratosis and solar keratosis.  
-  No evidence of malignancy seen.

MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr N Doggette) 
The resected material consists of ependymoma, choroid plexus and cerebellar cortex.  The ependymoma shows prominent perivascular pseudorosettes but there are no convincingependymal rosettes (EMA stain), no necrosis and no microvascular proliferation. The tumour appears cellular and the nuclei mildly pleomorphic. The mitotic rate is estimated at 2/10 HPF and the Ki67 is ~10% in the worst areas.  

COMMENT:
In my view, this tumour should be classified as ependymoma, WHO grade 2 as the only high grade feature is a relatively high Ki67.  There has been no tumour progression from the initial resection.

CLINICAL:
Whipple's resection + gallbladder. Pancreatic head mass, ? ca. + portal vein involvement.  Neoadjuvant chemotherapy.  Increased CA 19.9.
Additional: 
Further history from Dr Jackso:  
-  Nodes negative in previous selective intraabdominal lymph node dissection at TOCUMWAL Hospital.
-  Dr Cutri attended the ONCOLOGY (GYNAE) Pathology department to assist in identifying and orienting the resection margins including the portal vein wall margin.
MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled "Whipple's", consists of duodenum, 155mm in length ,stomach including pylorus 22mm in length, pancreatic head, 28mm (medial to lateral) x 42mm (inferior to superior) x 50mm (superficial to deep) and stented extrapancreatic common bile duct , 45mm in length and 7mm in maximum diameter. The specimen includes attached gallbladder 95mm x 45mm, greater omentum 80 x 30 x 15mm and lesser omentum 25 x 25 x 10mm. There are two separate pieces of presumed greater omental tissue 360 and 80mm in maximum dimension with an area of grey discolouration 40 x 35 x 10mm identified on one surface. The margins are inked as follows: pancreatic neck resection margin black,  periuncinate soft tissue (SMA) resection margin green, the portal vein bed resection margin blue (including the portal vein wall identified by Dr Fechtner),  posterior retroperitoneal margin orange, anterior pancreatic surface purple and the inferior pancreaticsurface yellow.
 The cut surface reveals an ill-defined grey area (? tumour) with loss of lobular architecture in the anterior superior head of pancreas measuring approximately 25 x 22 x 12mm.  There is a firm yellow area within the adjacent fat (? fat necrosis ? tumour extension) measuring 12 x 12 x 8mm.  The pancreatic duct is not identified.   The common bile duct is patent via a stent which extends its full length to the opening at the ampulla of Vater, the latter with an unremarkable mucosal surface. The mucosa of the duodenum and stomach is unremarkable. The serosa of the gallbladder appears mildly haemorrhagic.  The maximum thickness of the wall is 3mm.  No gallstones are identified.  One large lymph node 15mm is identified in the attached greater omental fat and multiple small lymph nodes are identified around the common bile duct margin.  
Block 1 - common bile duct margin; 2 - bowel and stomach resection margins; 3-9 - TS of pancreas to small bowel; 10-14 - full face of pancreas from inferior to superior; 15-20 - TS superior end of pancreas (paired blocks 16/17, 18/19); 21 & 22 - large greater omentum lymph node; 23 - lymph nodes around common bile duct; 24 - ? lesser omentum lymph nodes; 25 - ? greater omentum lymph node; 26 -representative gallbladder; 27-30 - representative greater omentum. Please refer to attached diagram.  (TO: CV;CT/ec 2.8.62) 
 MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr S Matro) 
Sections show a moderately to poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma centred within pancreatic head.  The tumour is predominantly  composed of small to large round to angulated glands with moderate to focally marked nuclear pleomorphism, occasionally  prominent nucleoli, eosinophilic cytoplasm, foci of goblet cell differentiation and patchy intraluminalnecrosis.  There are also numerous foci of single cell infiltration. 
Extent
The tumour has an infiltrative margin and focally extends into the wall of the stented intrapancreatic common bile duct, infiltrates around the pancreatic duct and extensively infiltrates the wall of the duodenum reachingnon-ulcerated mucosa.  The tumour invades fibrous tissue in proximity to the portal vein wall but no mural smooth muscle invasion is seen. There is also extrapancreatic invasion into adipose tissue posteriorly (perineural spread) and into adipose tissue between the duodenal wall and pancreas superiorly (contiguous invasion and perineural spread).  Extensiveperineural invasion is present both within the confines of tumour and as outlying foci.  A focus of mural vascular invasion is present and foci suspicious for lymphovascular invasion present, including within the duodenal wall.  Retractionartefact around tumour does make assessment of lymphovascular invasion difficult. 
Tumour response to therapy:
Although there is some fibrosis around tumour, there is extensive residual tumour and no significant tumour necrosis.  The tumour regression grade is therefore 3 (poor response).
Margins
The pancreatic neck margin is 0.2mm from tumour, the portal vein margin <0.1mm from tumour (with perineural invasion 0.2mm from this margin) while the portal vein wall resection margins is at least 0.5mm from tumour (some sectioning disruption of this margin limits assessment). The periuncinate margin is >5.5mm clear and the posterior retroperitoneal surface is 4mm clear.  The extrahepatic common bile duct, duodenal and gastric margins are all well clear.
 
Other pathology
The pancreas shows associated changes of chronic pancreatitis with ductolobular atrophy, fibrosis and chronic inflammation.  Away from the tumour there is mucinous and goblet cell metaplasia of ductules and focal mucinous metaplasia with micropapillae formation in a larger duct (PanIN/L 1B).  Changes consistent with previous surgery are present with suture/foreign body granulomas with the greater omentum and serosa of stomach plus chronic inflammation and fat necrosis with admixed giant cells within the peripancreatic fat.  The area of grey discolouration described in the greater omentum comprises fibrosis and suture granulomas.  Within adipose tissue posterior to the pancreas, there is also an abscess containing filamentous material suggestive of Actinomyces organisms.  The common bile duct shows mucosal erosions, mural acute inflammation and reactive epithelial atypia consistent with stent-related injury.  The gallbladder shows mucosal haemorrhage and mild chronic cholecystitis. A synoptic report for pancreatic exocrine carcinoma follows:

The ellipse of skin measures 127 x 35mm and the surface of the skin appears unremarkable.  The underlying subcutaneous tissue and muscle measures 110 x 60 x 30mm.  There are two sutures as designated (long lateral, short superior, the short suture is designated 12 o'clock and the long suture designated 3 o'clock. (TO: ZC:  RT/mm 2.12.63)
MICROSCOPIC:  (Reported by Dr U Protano)
Sections are of skin extending to deep subcutaneous tissue, including skeletal muscle at the deep aspect. The 40mm subcutaneous tumour is a high grade sarcomatoid tumour. The tumour consists of moderately to markedly atypical stellate to spindled cells withina variably fibromyxoid and hyalinised stroma. The tumour cells are arranged in sheets, poorly formed fascicular structures and in a storiform pattern surrounded by vascularised fibromyxoid stroma. Numerous highly atypical, bizarre multinucleated tumour cells are seen. In some areas, hyalinised bands of osteoid-like material separate malignant tumour cells (osteoid present in approximately 10% of tumour). Focal chondroid matrix and calcified bone formation are also seen. The tumour shows increased mitotic activity, includingscattered atypical mitoses. Very occasional foci of necrosis (up to 5%) are present. The tumour infiltrates the surrounding fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle, and numerous degenerate skeletal muscle fibres are seen. The surrounding adipose tissue contains scattered atypical cells, however, no lipoblasts are identified. Background epidermal and dermocutaneous changes in keeping with history of previous radiotherapy are seen. An incidental benign naevus (clear of margins) is present. 
The margins are as follows:
12 o'clock margin: 4.4mm (block 5).
3 o'clock margin: Well clear (>10mm).
6 o'clock margin: Focal positive margin (block 7).
9 o'clock margin: Well clear (>10mm). 
Deep margin: 1.7mm (blocks 9 and 12).

IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY:
Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the results are as follows:
Tumour cells positive for: Vimentin.
Tumour cells negative for: Cam5.2, Pancytokeratin, CD34, desmin, LCA, myogenin, S100 and SMA. 
Ki-67: Variable, up to 15% of tumour cell nuclei positive.

COMMENT:
The 40mm subcutaneous righttrapezius tumour is a high grade malignant sarcomatoid tumour. The overall morphology and pattern of immunohistochemical staining are those of a high grade pleomorphic sarcoma with focal osteosarcomatous component (approximately 10%). 
The surrounding adipose tissue contains scattered atypical stellate cells, with smudgy chromatin and cytoplasm and variably prominent nucleoli. The possibility of a dedifferentiated liposarcoma has been considered and cannotbe entirely excluded. However, the atypia in the surrounding adipose tissue may represent single cell infiltration of fat by malignant sarcoma cells, or alternatively, radiotherapy induced atypia. However, as a dedifferentiated liposarcoma cannot be entirely excluded, FISH testing for MDM2 amplification may be useful if clinically indicated. 
Please correlate with clinical and imaging findings. 


DIAGNOSIS:
Lesion right trapezius: 
High grade pleomorphic sarcoma with focal osteosarcomatous component (approximately 10%).
Tumour present focally at 6 o'clock margin. 
Please see comment.

Focal lymphvascular invasion is seen.  
The ectocervix and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.  Both ovaries and tubes are unremarkable.
B.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
C.  One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy.
D.  Five lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.
E.  Two lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS:
Grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, depth 14mm through a wall16mm thick.  Focal lymphvascular invasion is present.  Cervix uninvolved.  The omentum and eight lymph nodes are negative.
ADDITIONAL REPORT 7/2/63:
As requested, immunoperoxidase stains for MSI proteins were performed.  MLH1, PMS2, MSH2, MSH6 all show preserved nuclear staining.  This indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

MICROSCOPIC (reported by Dr H Moustafa):
A. The right ovarian parenchyma shows diffuse involvement by a well differentiated mucinous tumour. The mucinous tumour displays positive staining with CDX2 and CK 20, and negative staining with CK 7.This immunohistochemical profile is consistent with a tumour with an intestinal phenotype. Section of the right fallopian tube shows no significant abnormality.
B. The endometrium, ectocervix and endocervix show surface involvement by a well differentiated mucinous tumour with features similar to those seen in the appendix and right ovary. The myometrium contains a benign leiomyoma. The left fallopian tube shows a 1mm focus of carcinoma in situ/high grade dysplasia (Block B9). The left ovary shows no significant abnormality.
C. The appendix has been totally blocked and examined in its entirety. The appendix shows close to total replacement of its normal mucosa with a mostly flat and focally undulating mucinous epithelial proliferation. The mucinous epithelium shows mild cytological atypia and mitoses are not prominent. The wall of the appendix displays an altered morphology in areas and appears fibrotic and hyalinised. There is no discernible lamina propria. Diverticula of the tumour areseen focally but there is no evidence of rupture or invasion. The appearance is consistent with a low grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasm. Normal looking colonic mucosa is seen at the resection margin of the specimen.
D. Sections show the presence of extracellular mucin expanding the visceral peritoneum of the spleen. The appearance is consistent with pseudomyxoma peritonei although no epithelial component is identified. The splenic parenchyma shows no significant abnormality. 
E to L. Sections of peritoneum and omentum shows pools of extracellular mucin associated with varying degrees of mesothelial hyperplasia, vascular proliferation and a moderate mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate. The appearance is consistent with pseudomyxoma peritonei although no epithelial component is identified.
COMMENT: In women with pseudomyxoma peritonei and concomitant ovarian and appendiceal tumours, recent immunohistochemical, molecular and genetic evidence supports an origin in the appendix in most cases, and secondary involvement of the peritoneum and ovaries (1).

B. Uterus, cervix, left fallopian tube and ovary
- WELL DIFFERENTIATED MUCINOUS TUMOUR INVOLVING THE SURFACES OF THE ENDOMETRIUM, ENDOCERVIX AND ECTOCERVIX (SEE COMMENT)
- A 1MM FOCUS OF CARCINOMA IN SITU IN LEFT FALLOPIAN TUBE
- BENIGN LEIOMYOMA

D to L. Spleen, right peritoneum of diaphragm, left peritoneum of diaphragm, right lower quadrant peritoneum, left lower quadrant peritoneum, peritoneum left of liver, peritoneum, omentum, left abdominal wall
- PSEUDOMYXOMA PERITONEI (SEE COMMENT)
- NO EPITHELIAL COMPONENT IDENTIFIED
Reference: 
(1) Misdraji J. Appendiceal Mucinous neoplasms: Controversial Issues. Arch Pathol Lab Med. Vol 134, June 2010: 864 - 870.

MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr T Kennady):
A.  Sections show a 7.5mm minimally invasive adenocarcinoma, mucinous subtype.  Peripherally the carcinoma shows a lepidic growth pattern with large columnar cells lining alveoli.  The tumour cells have basally oriented, mildly pleomorphic nuclei with variably conspicuous nucleoli and abundant pale to eosinophilic cytoplasm containing apical mucin. Centrally there is a 4.2mm zone of acinar growth with associated stromal fibrosis and chronicinflammation consistent with invasion.  No necrosis, lymphovascular invasion or perineural invasion are seen. The pleura is uninvolved. The tumour is 30mm clear of the bronchovascular resection margin and there is no evidence of carcinoma in situ at this margin. There are peritumoural intraalveolar foamy histiocytes (obstructive pneumonia) which, with the tumour, spans 12mm, collections of pigmented intra-alveolar macrophages and minor foci of organising pneumonia.  Away from the tumour the lung parenchyma, including the pale areas detected grossly, are unremarkable.  One peribronchial lymph node shows anthracotic changeonly. 
Immunohistochemistry:
The tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7
Negative: CK20, TTF1.
COMMENT:
In the appropriate clinical and radiological context the morphological features and immunoprofile are consistent with a lung primary.  The absence of TTF 1 expression is not against a lung primary as primary mucinous adenocarcinomas of the lung are frequently TTF1 negative.  The appearances, however, are not specific as a metastatic adenocarcinoma from the upper gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas or biliary tract could also display similar morphology.  Clinical and radiological correlation is required.
B.  One lymph node shows anthracotic change only. There is no evidence of malignancy. 
C.  One lymph node shows anthracotic change only. There is no evidence of malignancy.

MICROSCOPIC (Reported by A/Prof V Rindler & Dr V Garbarino):

Sections show clear cell renal cell carcinoma of the kidney.  The tumour has a nested growth pattern of polygonal cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, centrally located round to oval nuclei and moderately conspicuous nucleoli. There is a fine vascular network of branching capillaries.  
The carcinoma is confined within the renal capsule and does not extend into the renal sinus fat.  
Tumour extends into the renal vein with invasion of the muscular vessel wall. 
Immunoprofile: CD 10 and Vimentin show strong positive staining. 
CD117 and CK 7 arenegative. The immunohistochemical profile is consistent with clear cell renal cell carcinoma, although some morphological features raise the possibility of chromophobe RCC. Dr V Hust has also reviewed the immunohistochemical panel and agrees with this diagnosis.
Sections of the adrenal gland are unremarkable.  No lymph nodes are identified.
The uninvolved renal parenchyma shows patchy chronic interstitial inflammation.

D.  Sections show mature adipose tissue. There is no evidence of malignancy.
E.  Sections show fragments of skeletal muscle. There is no evidence of malignancy.
F.  Sections show fragments of fibroadipose tissue including some admixed skeletal muscle and small calibre nerves. There is no evidence of malignancy. 
G.  Sections show fragments of fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle. There is no evidence of malignancy. 
H.  Sections show a mixed serous and mucinous salivary gland, consistent with parotid gland. The normal lobular architecture is preserved. There is patchy mild non-specific chronic inflammation within scattered lobules. No granulomas or pathogenic organisms are seen. A single lymph node shows reactive changes (0/1). There is no evidence of malignancy.  
I.  Sections of the twelve level 2/3 lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy (0/12). 
J.  Sections show mature fibroadipose tissue containing admixed skeletal muscle. There is an 11mm focus of moderately to poorly differentiated infiltrative carcinoma. 
K.  Sections are of skin extending to deep subcutaneous tissue, including salivary gland parenchyma and skeletal muscle at thedeep aspect. There is an extensive moderately to poorly differentiated infiltrative squamous cell carcinoma, which appears to arise from overlying epidermal Bowen's disease. The squamous cell carcinoma infiltrates throughout thedermis into subjacent skeletal muscle and salivary gland tissue, to a maximum depth of invasion of 20mm. There is multifocal perineural invasion. No convincing lymphovascular space invasion is seen. The carcinoma is 10mm from the closestperipheral margin (3 o'clock margin) and is very close to the deep margin (0.25mm) (K7 L2). Bowen's disease appears clear of the margins. The carcinoma shows strong positivity for the keratin stains (AE1/AE3, CK5/6 and Cam5.2) and is negative for S100. A single subcutaneous lymph node shows reactive changes (0/1). The adjacent skin shows an actinic keratosis and seborrheic keratosis.  
L.  Sections show variably dense fibrocollagenous tissue.The tissue shows patchy myxoid and hyaline degenerative type change. Focally, there are scattered cleft like cystic spaces, with variably dense fibrous walls and lined by plump histiocytoid cells. No true epithelial lining is identified.The overall appearance is in keeping with the clinical impression of a ganglion. There is no significant inflammation or evidence of crystal deposition. No pathogenic organisms or well formed granulomas are identified. There is no evidence of malignancy.

I.  Level 2 and 3 parotid gland: No evidence of malignancy in twelve lymph nodes (0/12). 

J.  Deep specimen: Invasive carcinoma present. 

K.  Left cheek/parotid tumour: 
Moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma arising on a background of Bowen's disease and showing multifocal perineural invasion.
Invasive carcinoma is very close to the deep margin (less than 0.25mm) and is 10mm to the closest peripheral margin (3o'clock).

A separate 15mm peduculated polyp is identified, 5mm from one resection margin.  The mucosa is otherwise unremarkable.  Multiple lymph nodes are identified in the mesenteric fat.
Blocks:  1 - one resection margin; 2 - one resection margin to a large polyp; 3 & 4 - tumour and mesenteric resection margin; 5 to 7 - full face of tumour; 8 - further representative tumour; 9 - tumour to uninvolved mucosa; 10 to 13 - lymph nodes; 14 - reserved block.  Please refer to attached diagram.  (TO: XI; UT/rt 12.11.63)
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr R Bellanca):
Sections show a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with the following features:
Macroscopic Description

Site of tumour:  Sigmoid colon	
Maximum tumour diameter:    43mm
Distance of tumour to nearer cut end:    55mm
Tumour perforation:     No
Microscopic Description

Type
Adenocarcinoma NOS
Differentiation by predominant area
Moderate
The tumour is composed of variably sized complex and cribriform glandular structures lined by columnar cells with moderately pleomorphic nuclei.  There is patchy central luminal necrosis.
Local invasion
pT3	Beyond muscularis propria
The tumour contiguously invade the mesocolon extending to the mesocolic margin and very close to the serosal surface with an associated fibroinflammatory reaction, however no tumour cells are seen on the serosal surface.

Comment
Tumour cells with a fibro-inflammatory response are seen within 1mm of the serosal surface.  Although this would be classified as pT3 under AJCC 7th Ed., recent studies suggest these cases have a prognosis similar to pT4a lesions (1)
(1) Panarelli et al. Histologic Features and Cytologic Techniques That Aid Pathologic Stage Assessment of Colonic Adenocarcinoma, Am J Surg Pathol 2013;37:1252-1258
Tumour involvement of margins
Cut ends: Not involved 
Non-peritonealised circumferential margin: Involved	 (mesocolic margin)
Lymph nodes
Number of lymph nodes present: 13	
Number of lymph nodes involved: 1 (several nests distributed over 3mm)
Number of mesocolic tumour satellite nodules: 2
In addition to one involved lymph node, there are two mesenteric deposits of adenocarcinoma which are non-contiguous with the invasive front of tumour.  No discernable residual lymph node architecture or vessel wall is seen.Both deposits are therefore regarded as mesocolic satellite nodules.
pN1a	Metastases in 1 regional LN
Lymphovascular invasion
Present   
Several foci of extramural (subserosal) invasion of small thin walled vessels are seen (probable lymphatic) (block 10).
Perineural invasion
Present  
Several foci of extramural perineural invasion and a focus of extramural intraneural invasion (block 3) are seen including close to the involved mesenteric margin (block 6). 
Histologically confirmed distant metastases
pMX	Cannot be assessed histologically (clinical history of metastases)
Background abnormalities/other comments
Adenomas:  The 15mm peduculated polyp is a tubulovillous adenoma with low grade epithelial dysplasia.  The polyp is about 5mm clear of the closest resection margin.
Other:  Away from the tumour and polyp, the bowel mucosa is unremarkable.
Residual tumour status
R2	Macroscopic margin involvement
The gross impression of involvement of the mesocolon margin(cut surface of the mesocolon) is confirmed with tumour extending to this margin over a front of approximately 7.5mm.
Mismatch Repair Deficiency (MMRD) Status	
MLH1		Preserved nuclear staining
PMS2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH6		Preserved nuclear staining
Comment:
Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.
Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

Stage - TNM 7th Edition
pT3  (see comment) N1a MX R2	
DIAGNOSIS:
Sigmoid colon:
-  Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma invading mesocolon, extramural lymphovascular invasion, extramural perineural and intraneural invasion, positive mesocolic margin, metastatic adenocarcinoma in one (1) of thirteen (13) lymph nodes (1/13), two (2) mesocolic tumour satellite nodules; clinical history of metastases.

-  Tubulovillous adenoma with low grade dysplasia, clear of margins.

CLINICAL:
Lt hemihepatectomy. 
MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled "Liver resection", consists of a liver weighing 267g and measuring 115 x 90 x 75mm.  Most of the outer surface of liver is covered by capsule with a rough resection maring measuring 80 x 30mm, inked blue.  Capsular surface is smooth and there is no defect.  On the cut surface most of the liver is occupied by well circumscribed pale soft and haemorrhagic tumour measuring 85 x 80 x 65mm.  It comes close to resection margin measuring 3mm.  Rim of unremarkable liver parenchyma is noted around the tumour.  
Blocks: 1 and 2 - paired section within resection margin; 3 and 4 - paired section within resection; 5 - section of resection margin; 6 and 7 - section of tumour with capsular surface; 8 - uninvolved liver.  
(TO: CT;CF/vo 16.1.63) 
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr F Keamo):
The 85mm tumour is a spindle cell neoplasm with similar features to the previous excisions (24Y54792 and 24Y54792).  The tumour is relatively circumscribed with a thin fibrous pseudocapsule in areas, but also shows focal areas of infiltration into adjacent hepatocellular parenchyma as well as entrapment of portal structures.  The cellulartumour shows a haphazard, sheet-like and focally storiform arrangement of spindle cells with densely eosinophilic, somewhat granular cytoplasm, mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism, finely granular chromatin and single to multiple small eosinophilic nucleoli.  The tumour contains red blood cell-filled pseudovascular spaces, as well as capillary size vessels.  Occasional fibrous septa containing dilated vessels are also present.  There is a focal tumour necrosis (approximately 5% of tumour) and acute haemorrhage. Focal lymphovascular invasion is seen (block 3).  Tumour cell mitoses number up to 28 per 10hpf.  The tumour is 1.1mm from the resection margin (block 2)
Immunohistochemistry:  
The tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive - CD34 (multifocal), Vimentin.
Equivocal - EMA (patchy peripheral staining with background staining of liver)
Negative - CAM 5.2, Pan CK, AE1/AE3, Desmin, S100, HMB 45, Melan A, CD31, Hepar-1, CD117 (patchy minimal cytoplasmic staining with background cytoplasmic staining of  hepatocytes.)
COMMENT 1:
The features are consistent with metastatic unclassifiable spindle cell sarcoma.  Unclassifiable spindle cell sarcoma was the diagnosis made on review by Prof. LOWELL PICCIONI in 2060 for the original pelvic tumour ; a more specific diagnosis was not possible.  The minimal patchy cytoplasmic CD117 staining with background hepatocellular staining in this case, is regarded as a negative result, especially in the context of previous negative DOG1 staining on two separate occasions.  
The adjacent liver shows overall preservedlobular architecture with very mild patchy portal chronic inflammation, mild fibrous expansion and focal linkage of portal tracts. There is very mild proliferation of bile ductules and periductal concentric fibrosis and possible oedema. A focal intraductal aggregate of acute inflammatory cells is also noted.  No steatosis or lobular inflammation is seen.  There is mild periportal hepatocyte copper deposition on rhodanine staining.  No stainable iron seen on Perls staining.  No dPAS positive globules seen. 
COMMENT 2:
The adjacent non-tumour liver shows changes suggestive of biliary obstruction, however, these changes may represent local effects secondaryto proximity to tumour.  Further clinicopathological correlation is necessary.
DIAGNOSIS:  
Left hemihepatectomy: 
-  Metastatic unclassifiable spindle cell sarcoma
-  1.1mm from the resection margin.

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT:  (21.1.63)

MOLECULAR TISSUE ANALYSIS, TARGETED BRAF MUTATION DETECTION.
Reported by Dr H Stricklind, ACT Genetic's Pathology. 
"BRAF MUTATION TEST:
Result:
Targeted BRAF mutation analysis on DNA extracted from FFPE tumour tissue:
NEGATIVE.
MUTATION NOT DETECTED.  

Interpretation:
The tumour sample from patient Simon HIGHLEY DOES NOT CARRY a known activating BRAF gene mutation that affects codon 600 of the BRAF protein (see comments). 
This patient is NOT expected to benefit from treatment with a BRAF inhibitor based therapy (Chapman et al. Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.  N Engl J Med 2011; 364:2507-16). 
Method:
*DNA was extracted from FFPE tumour tissue using the Roche cobas DNA Sample Preparation kit.
*BRAF gene mutations were analysed using the Roche cobas BRAF V600 Mutation Test kit (ARTG: 298901). 
COMMENTS:
*This test is intended as an adjunct to other prognostic and predictive factors to aid clinical treatment decisions. 
* This test does not specify the activating BRAF gene mutation that causes a substitution of the Valine at codon 600 (p.V600) of the BRAF protein. The test detects the common BRAF p.V600E (c.1799T>A) mutation, which occursin >80% of BRAF positive tumours, and may also detect some (but NOT all) activating BRAF p.V600K mutations, which occur in up to 17% of BRAF positive tumours. Other rare activating BRAF mutations affecting p.V600 may NOT be detected bythis analysis, therefore a negative result should be interpreted with caution. Other mutations, either in the BRAF gene or in other genes, will not be detected by this analysis. 
*This test has been shown in our laboratory to detect at least 5% mutant BRAF alleles in a background of normal DNA. Therefore a negative result should be interpreted with caution, as it does not exclude the presence of lowlevels of an activating BRAF mutation. 
*The analytical sensitivity and specificity of this test for the p.V600E mutation are 99.6% and 97.9%, respectively. PCR inhibitors or rare mutations affecting the binding sites of PCR primers and/or probes may cause a false negative result.
*This test has been processed as a Level 1 genetic test according to the NPAAC guidelines (2007).
*Only the testing performed byour laboratory is covered by NATA accreditation, not the referenced material used for clinical interpretation of this testing".

SPRText
CLINICAL:
Right forearm lesion suture proximal.  Tissue biobanking.  Sarcoma - previous XRT.


MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Right forearm lesion stitch proximal&quot;, consists of a 90 x 87 x 10mm somewhat circular excision of skin with a suture present towards one end as described and will be designated 12 o&apos;clock.  In the centre of the excision is a 50 x 43mm nodule.  Skeletal muscle is present on the deep surface.  3 o&apos;clock inked blue and 9 o&apos;clock inked black.  Specimen is sectioned from proximal to distal into nine slices.  There is a lobulated tan tumour 55 x 45 x 25mm.  The tumour is 22mm from the 3 o&apos;clock margin, 25mm from the 9 o&apos;clock margin and abuts the deep margin.  30% of the tumour is possibly necrotic and there are areas of myxoid change.  Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - LS proximal; 3 &amp; 4 - tumour; 5 &amp; 6 - tumour; 7 - closest 3 o&apos;clock margin; 8 to 12 - full face slice 5 (8 - closest  9 o&apos;clock margin); 13 to 15 - tumour; 16 &amp; 17 - LS (distal); 18 - biobank.  See diagram.  (TO:YL/ec 29/10/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr L Kurokawa):
Sections show skin excised to include subcutaneous fat plus a small amount of underlying skeletal muscle. There is a lobulated and somewhat circumscribed cellular tumour centred in the subcutaneous fat. The tumour focally bulges into deep dermis. The superficial dermis, epidermis and skeletal muscle are uninvolved. The tumour is composed of compact fascicles of plump spindle cells with moderate amounts of lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei and one to two nucleoli. Mitotic figures are occasionally seen and focally number up to 4 per 10 HPF. Necrosis is not identified. There are moderate numbers of admixed inflammatory cells including lymphocytes, plasma cells and eosinophils within the tumour. The tumour also shows nodular areas of hyalinisation and myxoid change associated with foamy histiocytes and haemosiderin laden macrophages. These alteration is regarded as treatment related changes and is seen in approximately 60% of the tumour. No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is seen.

The tumour cells show the following immunoprofile:
-  Positive:  EMA.
-  Equivocal:  S100 (scattered tumour cells, no more than 5%) and Melan A (faint cytoplasmic staining in around 1% of tumour cells).
-  Negative:  MNF116, Cam5.2, CK5/6, SOX10, HMB45, MUM1, CD34, SMA, desmin, myogenin, STAT6, MUC4 and ALK.
Nuclear expression of H3K37m3 is retained.
The Ki-67 proliferation index is up to around 10% at hotspots by visual estimation.

The overall features are those of a malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.

The cellular tumour mass itself is 1 mm from the deep margin (Block 14). However, the tissue deep to the tumour has a paucicellular and loose myxoid appearance in which there are interspersed atypical cells . These cells may represent reactive atypia in benign stromal cells although tumour cells with treatment effect can show a similar cytology and as such, definite clearance of tumour at the deep margin cannot be guaranteed. This loose myxoid change is present at the deep margin over at least a 5 mm front (Blocks 13, 14 &amp; 15). The tumour mass and deep loose myxoid stromal change are &gt; 10 mm from all peripheral margins.


DIAGNOSIS:
Excision of lesion, right forearm (post radiotherapy):  Malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with treatment effect

CLINICAL:
Biopsy = rhabdo sarcoma. Biobanking.


MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Right medial thigh lesion stitch proximal&quot;, consists of a 122 x 95 x 50mm ellipse excision of skin. The overlying ellipse of skin measures 122 x 62mm, which appears unremarkable. Specimen is received fresh and sampled for Biobanking  A suture is present is one tip which will be denoted at 12 o&apos;clock. Three o&apos;clock inked blue, 9 o&apos;clock inked green and deep inked black. The stitch will be designated 12 o&apos;clock. Specimen is sectioned from 12 to 6 o&apos;clock into eight slices. Situated within the subcutis and overlying the skeletal muscle is a 56 x 47 x 40mm irregular tan tumour. The tumour appears haemorrhagic and has a central necrotic area representing approximately 30% of the tumour. The tumour abuts the 9 o&apos;clock margin, is 6mm from the 3 o&apos;clock margin, abuts the dermis and is 3mm from the deep margin. The tumour is well clear of the 12 and 6 o&apos;clock margins. Block 1-2 - LS slice one (12 o&apos;clock); 3 - closest 9 o&apos;clock margin; 4 - closest deep margin 5 - tumour/skeletal muscle; 6 - closest 9 o&apos;clock margin; 7 - skin interface; 8 - deep margin; 9 - 3 o&apos;clock margin; 10 - central; 11 -  tumour/skeletal muscle; 12 - 9 o&apos;clock margin; 13 - 3 o&apos;clock margin - 14 - central; 15 - deep margin; 16-17 - LS slice eight (6 o&apos;clock margin); 18 - Biobank. Photos taken.  (TO:YL/kl 25/9/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr C Gilfoy):
RHABDOMYOSARCOMA SYNOPTIC REPORT (BIOPSY)
Morphologic description:
The tumour is located in the subcutis up to the interface with muscle and is mildly infiltrative without capsule and some entrapment of surrounding adipocytes. There is a moderately to variable markedly cellular spindled to epithelioid/rhabdoid cell proliferation with scattered osteoclastic type and tumour giant cells. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic but no unequivocal striation is seen. There appears to be a variable abrupt transition from lower to widespread higher grade/pleomorphic areas (best seen in 6). The nuclei show variation in size with mostly intermediate to scattered marked pleomorphism. The nuclei are ovoid with irregular nuclear membranes, some coarse chromatin and some show distinct nucleoli. There are areas of more prominent thick collagen bundles in between the tumour, hyalinisation and coagulative and infarct type necrosis. Florid mitotic activity is seen (31mitoses/10HPF with field diameter 0.55mm) including some atypical forms. The scattered single more prominent atypical cells (up to 3 times the size of the average tumour cell combined with atypical mitoses and the small circumscribed area of increased atypia are best regarded a focal areas of anaplasia.
The peripheral 9 o&apos;clock margin is best regarded as focally involved (3) at the level of subcutis and in another focus the 9 o&apos;clock margin is less than 0.1mm away (6). The 3 o&apos;clock peripheral margin is 4mm away.The deep margin is 1.6mm with an intact soft tissue plane (4). The other margins are further away.
The overlying skin shows moderate sun damage.

Immunohistochemistry:
The tumour cells are diffusely positive for desmin (cytoplasmic). SMA shows patchy positive staining. Myogenin (nuclear) shows scattered single and small aggregates of positive cells. INI-1 shows retained nuclear staining. EMA shows scattered single cells with rather membranous staining. Pancytokeratin shows scattered small aggregates of staining
The tumour cells are negative for ERG, Sox10 and S100.

The morphological and immunohistochemical features show some similarity to the previous description in the core biopsy report from DHM. In the outside core biopsy Myogenin and Pancytokeratin were negative in contrast to the current excision however this may represent sampling.

Comment: The features are those of a rhabdomyosarcoma with some spindled areas including tumour giant cells and some sclerosis associated with focal anaplasia. The features are favoured to represent spindle cell/sclerosing type with patchy areas of pleomorphism over pleomorphic subtype. Dr C Vergo concurs.

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT:

CLINICAL:
1. Retroperitoneal liposarcoma with segment of sigmoid colon. No neoadjuvant therapy.
2. Distal sigmoid colon with cicatrising lesion - previous endometriosis. Histopathology, tumour banking. No previous biopsy or FISH done


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Abdominal liposarcoma&quot;, sampled for biobanking,consists of a piece of bowel with attached mesocolon, 470 x 180 x 90mm.  There is also a separate piece of fatty tissue 65 x 30 x 12mm. Bowel margins inked black. Specimen inked blue and bisected into two halves.  The bowel is 200mm in length. The mucosa appears normal with no obvious polyp, lesion or tumour involvement. The mesocolon consists of multiple fatty nodules. The largest nodule is roughly 160 x 145 x 75mm. This nodule is mostly covered by peritoneum and has a lobulated fatty cut surface with no obvious necrosis or haemorrhage seen. The other mesocolon nodules also have a lobulated fatty cut surface or fleshy cut surface. Focally there is one nodule with a multinodular myxoid cut surface measuring 80 x 50 x 60mm, and is adjacent to the bowel but not involving the bowel. There is another nodular lesion adjacent to the bowel with a pale cut surface (? necrosis) measuring 30 x 25 x 25mm.
Blocks 1-15 - 15RS from the largest lesion (first half of specimen); 16-20 1RS from distant nodules and part of mesocolon (first half of specimen); 21 - presumed proximal bowel margin; 22 - presumed distal bowel margin; 23-24 - interface of bowel and pale/necrotic lesion (second half of specimen); 25 - interface of bowel and myxoid lesion (second half of specimen); 26-27- RS bowel adjacent to myxoid lesion (second half of specimen); 28-29 - interface of bowel and myxoid lesion (second half of specimen); 30- RS bowel and mesocolon (second half of specimen); 31-32 - interface of bowel and fleshy nodule (second half of specimen); 33-37 - 5RS of myxoid nodule (second half of specimen); 38-39 -2RS of fleshy nodule (second half of specimen); 40-41 - 2RS from a fatty nodule/mesocolon (second half of specimen); 42 - 1RS from another fatty nodule/mesocolon (second half of specimen); 43 - 1RS from another fleshy nodule (second half of specimen); 44 - possible lymph nodes as seen; 45 - biobank. Shown to Dr F Spataro.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Distal sigmoid colon&quot;, consists of an opened portion of bowel 45 x 40 x 20mm. There are two stapled margins removed and inked. The mucosa appears normal with no lesion or polyp. There is a possible diverticulum. Blocks 1-5 - 5RS of bowel. (TO:DN/ec 15/10/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr F Duprat):
A and B. The mesocolon/retroperitoneum shows widespread Well differentiated Liposarcoma.

The tumour is present throughout the blocks and shows mostly a lipomatous differentiation and smaller foci of sclerosing subtype (A43) and myxoid appearance. The tumour comprises predominantly adipose tissue with some areas showing fibrous septae. There are atypical nuclei in the adipose tissue including variation in size of adipocytes and septae including focal single multinucleated bizarre cells.. Lipoblasts are easily identified. There is abrupt transition to myxoid nodules (as seen macroscopically) and slow transition of more myxoid stroma. There are distinct nodules of sclerosing subtype (as seen macroscopically as nodules). Mitoses are very inconspiciuous. Small foci of fat necrosis are seen but there is no coagulative/tumour necrosis. There is no lymphovascular and no perineural invasion. The tumour extends to the stroma external to the muscularis propria of the colon in Specimen A but does not invade the muscularis propria. The stromal margins are involved and the colonic peripheral margins clear. Small portions of unremarkable fallopian tube are included (A16).

Some endometriosis is confirmed (Specimen B).

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr Q Holtham)
A. Sections of the cervix show some atrophic features and reactive epithelial changes.
The endometrium shows a polypoid lesion with overlying epithelial layer with underlying stroma that is cellular and with cytologic pleomorphism and mitotic activity. Scattered multinucleated giant cells are also seen. The appearances are those of adenosarcoma. The sarcoma appears to confine to polyp and the endometrium without evidence of myometrial invasion in the sections examined. Elsewhere with the myometrium, there are benign leiomyomas and adenomyosis. There is endometriosis with serosal adhesions and mesothelial rection with haemorrhage in the posterior uterine serosa/pouch of douglas.

Sections of the ovaries show serous cyst adenofibroma/serous inclusion with surface serosal adhesions and associated haemorrhage and macrophages reaction and with serosal endometriosis. The fallopian tubes are unremarkable.

Sections of the separate fragments of tissue consist of predominantly necrotic tumour including some fragments with a focal phyllodes-like growth pattern. There is a predominant stromal component (sarcomatous overgrowth). Some glands with columnar epithelium and with squamous metaplasia are identified. The stroma shows cytologic pleomorphism and increased cellularity with some subepithelial condensation. Multinucleated tumour giant cells are seen. Mitotic activity is present (up to 23 mitoses per 10 hpf).


B. The sections show mesothelium with reactive changes and with macrophage and chronic inflammatory reaction of the stroma including and with acute inflammatory reaction.

C. The sections show omentum with reactive surface epithelial change, mesothelial changes and macrophage reaction on the serosal surface

Comment: The appearances of the uterine tumour and separate fragments of tumour are those of adenosarcoma with sarcomatous overgrowth. It appears confined to the endometrium (stage 1A). There are also benign serous cystadenofibromas/serous inclusions  and endometriosis/serosal adhesions of the ovaries, and endometriosis/serosal adhesions of the posterior uterine serosa/pouch of douglas. Clinical correlation is recommended.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. UTERUS
- ADENOSARCOMA WITH SARCOMATOUS OVERGROWTH (STAGE 1A).

B. LARGE BOWEL SEROSA
- REACTIVE CHANGES/ADEHSIONS AND MIXED ACUTE AND CHRONIC INFLAMMATION.

C. OMENTUM
- NEGATIVE FOR MALIGNANCY.

MACROSCOPIC:
A. &quot;RIGHT PELVIC SIDEWALL&quot;. Consists of a piece of fibrofatty tissue with one smooth surface. It measures 65x40x35mm. Presumed resection margin is inked blue. Anterior is inked blue, posterior - black. Adnexal tissue is separated from the main specimen. The uterus with cervix weighs 66g and it measures 80mm superior to inferior, 30mm intercornual distance. Ectocervix is 30x25mm with an ovoid os 2mm. It is creamed coloured and unremarkable. Anterior endomyometrium measures 17mm, posterior endomyometrium measures 15mm. The endometrium is less than 1mm thick. On sectioning, there is a calcified nodule consistent with a fibroid noted posteriorly. This measures 15x15x10mm. There is a possible polyp noted attached to the anterior wall and measuring 3mm. No other suspicious area is identified. The right ovary and fallopian tube weighs 7g. Fallopian tube measures 45mm in length with a maximum diameter of 6mm. The serosa and fimbria appear unremarkable. Ovary is 25x12x6mm. Serosa is unremarkable.
