(1 anterior, posterior cervix; 2,3 anterior, posterior endomyometrium; 4 possible polyp; 5 right fallopian tube; 6 right ovary; 7 left fallopian tube; 8 left ovary). Representative sections (M-8)

C. &quot;RIGHT DIAPHRAGMATIC WALL&quot;. Consists of fatty tissue with one surface peritonealised. It measures 120x100x50mm. There is a nodule measuring 80x80x40mm. The non-peritonealised resection margin is inked blue. On sectioning through the nodule, it has a pale white to haemorrhagic cut surface and appears to come up to the resection margin. It is sectioned from one end to the other into 14 slices. (1-4 sections from Slice 1; 5 and 6 sections from Slice 6; 7 and 8 sections from Slice 9; 9 section from Slice 12). Representative sections (M-9)

D. &quot;OMENTUM&quot;. Consists of omental tissue measuring 300x100x25mm. There are multiple nodular deposits of tumour with a pale white appearance. They range from 6-20mm. Representative sections taken. (M-2)

E. &quot;APPENDICES EPIPLOICAE&quot;. A piece of fatty tissue 15x10x6mm. There is a pale area ?fat necrosis measuring 6mm, bisected. All embedded. (2-1)

F. &quot;LEFT PELVIC SIDEWALL&quot;. Consists of two pieces of fatty tissue with an aggregate measurement of 90x40x10mm. On surface is peritonealised. Opposite surface is not peritonealised and this is inked blue. On sectioning, there is a nodular deposit of tumour measuring 20x15x7mm. Representative sections (M-1)

G. &quot;LEFT ANTERIOR ABDOMINAL WALL&quot;. Consists of two pieces of fatty tissue in aggregate 30x30x10mm. On sectioning, the cut surface is variegated. All embedded.
(1 first piece bisected; 2 second piece bisected). All embedded. (M-2/MC 3/7/2071 cy)

MICROSCOPIC: Dr L Vonthethoff  cy

A. Right Pelvic Sidewall:
Sections show fatty connective tissue with an overlying layer of peritoneal mesothelium. The subsurface tissue is extensively involved by an infiltrative malignancy which has a predominantly cystic pseudoglandular architecture. The spaces are lined by large epithelial cells with moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. The nuclei show variable atypia. There are some papillary structures present. In intervening stromal tissue there is a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate and there are some aggregates of foam cells. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes. The subsurface epithelial proliferation merges with overlying mesothelial cells. Some cells contain cytoplasmic vacuoles.

The histologic features are consistent with MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA.
See specimen G for Immunohistochemistry.
There is deep invasion of subsurface fat by mesothelioma.

B. Uterus, Bilateral Tubes And Ovaries:
- Ectocervical mucosa is normal. Endocervical mucosa is normal. The endometrium is inactive and there is focal inactive adenomyosis present. There is a small intramural leiomyoma. The serosal/peritoneal surface of the uterus shows no abnormality.
- The right ovary has some surface fibrous adhesions and small microcalcifications within granulation tissue. There is reactive mesothelial hyperplasia.
- The right fallopian tube shows no significant abnormality.
- The left ovary shows areas of surface reactive mesothelial hyperplasia, and some small surface fibrous adhesions and granulation tissue. Within the granulation tissue, there are embedded aggregates of psammoma bodies.
- The left fallopian tube shows no significant abnormality.
Tumour is not identified in this specimen.

C. Right Diaphragmatic Wall:
Sections show fatty subperitoneal tissue with a surface layer of peritoneal mesothelium. There is a subsurface partly solid and partly cystic mass with a papillary, solid and pseudoglandular architecture of similar appearance to the tumour in specimen A (MESOTHELIOMA). The subsurface lesion has an invasive growth pattern and involves much of the specimen. The cells have a variable decidoid appearance. There is a stromal inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes in areas and some xanthoma cells. Some psammoma bodies are present. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes.  The tumour invades some attached skeletal muscle in one  section (C7). There is overlying mesothelial hyperplasia, fibrous adhesions and areas of granulation tissue and in some areas there are aggregates of psammoma bodies.

D. Omentum:
The omental tissue contains deposits of MESOTHELIOMA.

E. Appendices Epiploicae:
Sections show fatty tissue with MESOTHELIOMA. There are also some aggregates of foamy histiocytes and cholesterol crystals and moderate numbers of psammomatous calcifications.

F. Left Pelvic Sidewall:
Sections show subperitoneal fatty tissue with subsurface involvement by MESOTHELIOMA.
There is deep invasion of subsurface fat.

G. Left Anterior Abdominal Wall:
Sections show fatty tissue with involvement by MESOTHELIOMA. There is deep invasion of subsurface fat. There are some sheets of foamy histiocytes associated with the tumour and a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes and plasma cells. The tumour cells have a decidual appearance.

IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY (IHC), block G2
Other suitable block for testing: A2
Positive: WT1, Podoplanin (D2-40), calretinin, CK5/6 (all 3+ positive)
Negative: CD31, MOC-31, CEA, PAX8, ER, TTF1, CEA.
BAP1: Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear staining

COMMENT on IHC:
The Immunohistochemical profile is consistent with mesothelioma. Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear BRCA-associated protein 1 (BAP1) is a highly specific marker of malignancy in mesothelial lesions. In the current case there are other diagnostic features of malignancy (in particular deep invasion of subsurface tisssues).

OTHER STAINS:
DPAS: negative (section G2)

SUMMARY OF TUMOUR FEATURES (all deposits):
Tumour type:
- Diffuse malignant mesothelioma, epithelioid type.

Size of largest tumour nodule:
- 80x80x40mm (right diaphragmatic wall)

Extent of invasion:
- Invasion into subsurface fat (at least 20mm depth). Focal invasion of skeletal muscle in right diaphragmatic wall specimen (?focal diaphragm invasion)

Mitotic count:
- 1 per 10 high power fields

Margins:
- Not applicable, but tumour involves margins of some pieces.

Staging:
- I am unaware of an agreed formal staging system for peritoneal mesothelioma.

OTHER COMMENT(S):
- There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) in most areas of the tumour.
- MMRP deficiency is rare in mesothelioma and has not been tested.
- Tumour tissue is retained if testing for other biomarkers is required.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DIAGNOSIS:
A,C,D,E,F,G. Right pelvic sidewall, right diaphragmatic wall, omentum, appendices epiploicae, left pelvic sidewall, left anterior abdominal wall:
-  PERITONEAL DIFFUSE EPITHELIOID MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA;
-  see comment(s).
B. Uterus, Bilateral Tubes and Ovaries:
-  no no significant abnormality.

Pathology ReportCLINICAL:
Retroperitoneal tumour (?sarcoma). Para-aortic mass. Core needle biopsy (DHM) reported high grade sarcomatoid  tumour. Previous history of a testicular germ cell tumour approximately 13yrs ago and had retroperitoneal lymph node dissection. Para-aortic tumour en block resection with infra-renal aorta.

Confirmed with Dr SHAWN DEANGELES (surgical oncology fellow) that main specimen does not require formal orientation as tumour macroscopically extend to margins (AP 16/3/71).


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Para-cable mass (?sarcoma)&quot;, consists of a 25 x 15 x 10mm nodule with a cream and vaguely nodular cut surface. Bisected and half embedded for frozen section.  Blocks: 1 - frozen section; 2 - remaining tissue. AE.
B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Peri-aortic tumour&quot;, consists of a segment of aorta 43mm long to a diameter of 17mm (lumen 10mm) with surrounding adherent soft tissue, 50 x 42 x 35mm. Tissue is sampled fresh for biobanking. No anatomical landmarks are present for definite orientation (confirmed with surgical team orientation not required). The tissue is arbitrarily inked blue and black. The cut surface shows heterogeneous soft tissue surrounding a fibrotic aortic wall with focal fatty streaks. Whilst heterogeneous soft tissue may represent tumour, no measurable discrete lesion is identified. Numerous lymph nodes measuring up to 7mm in greatest dimension are distributed throughout the soft tissue. No tumour thrombus or luminal thrombus formation is seen. Blocks: 1 - TS one end (partial aorta); 2 - full face of tumour (big block); 3 to 5 - composite section; 6 to 8 - composite section; 9 &amp; 10 - composite section; 11 - TS shave other end aorta. Macroscopic photo available.
C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left retro-caval&quot;, consists of a nodular piece of tan and white tissue, 13 x 6 x 5mm.   AE 1 block.
D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right superior renal mass&quot;, consists of an irregular piece of fibrofatty tissue, 35 x 28 x 13mm. The cut surface has a heterogeneous fibrofatty appearance. Blocks: 1 - TS ends; 2 &amp; 3 - TS through middle. AE.
E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Anterior aortic tissue at renal vessels&quot;, consists of a strip of fibrous tissue, 15 x 5 x 2mm.   AE 1 block.   (TO:AP/ta 16/3/71)
FROZEN SECTION REPORT:
A. Fibrosis bland cartilage and epithelium. If previous testicular tumour is a germ cell tumour may represent treatment effect with mature teratoma. Discussed with the surgical reg. Previous orchidectomy performed in New Zealand 15yrs ago.
Result phoned to Surgical registrar by Dr J Stencel and Dr J Sacks at 12:15 on 12/1/21.


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr J Ernspiker):
A. Paraffin embedded sections show fibrocollagenous tissue with patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis containing scattered islands of mature cartilage. A simple mucin lined ductule is also seen. In the clinical context of previous testicular tumour this is favoured to represent a focus of residual mature teratoma with treatment effect/fibrosis. There is no evidence of malignant germ cell tumour or sarcoma.

B. Sections show aorta with surrounding peri-aortic tissue. There is extensive involvement of the fibrotic periaortic soft tissue by an infiltrative malignant sarcomatoid tumour. In the blocks submitted, the overall estimated maximum tumour dimension is 22mm (however, tumour is present at the margin and total tumour extent cannot be determined). The tumour is composed of malignant spindled to epithelioid cells arranged in dense cellular infiltrative sheets which dissect through periaortic fibrocollagen. In areas, the tumour cells appear to form malignant, anastomosing vascular channels lined by malignant hobnailed endothelial cells. The vasoformative tumour abuts and infiltrates into the adventitia and outer media of the aorta. Mitoses are readily identified and there are scattered foci of tumour necrosis. The tumour shows extensive crush type artefact and multifocal perineural involvement. The tumour extends broadly to the edges of the excision.

Five lymph nodes are identified, one of which shows direct infiltration by tumour (1/5).

Immunohistochemistry demonstrates positivity for vascular markers ERG, CD31 and CD34, as well as, BCL-2 (patchy), synaptophysin (weak),  Additional stains for inhibin, myogenin, LCA, WT1 (cytoplasm staining only), PLAP, AFP, desmin, tdt, pancytokeratin, CD56, SMA, TLE-1, MIC-2, CAM5.2, SOX-10 and OCT-34 are negative. INI-1 shows preserved (normal) nuclear staining.

In addition, within the surrounding fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue, there are occasional foci of cartilage on a background of broad nodules and sheets of dense organised fibrosis with  superimposed dystrophic calcification, fat necrosis and inflammation. Several entrapped medium to large nerves and ganglia are also seen. These background changes are suggestive of focal residual mature teratoma on a background of previous treatment related effect.

C. Section show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. No cartilage is seen. There is no evidence of malignancy.

D. Sections show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. A 1.1mm focus of adrenal cortical parenchyma, as well as, seven reactive appearing lymph nodes (0/7). No cartilage is seen. There is no evidence of malignancy.

E. Section show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. A single reactive lymph node is seen. No cartilage is identified. There is no evidence of malignancy.


COMMENT:
The presence of islands of residual mature cartilage associated with organising fibrosis, inflammation, dystrophic calcification and fat necrosis in specimens A and B (para caval and peri aortic masses), is highly suggestive of residual mature teratoma on a background of treatment associated change. No evidence of malignant germ cell elements are seen.

As reported in the previous biopsy by Professor Jaussen, there is an associated peri-aortic high grade malignant sarcoma, which may represent: (a) malignant transformation arising within the previously treated para-aortic tumour; (b) or, a de novo sarcoma. In these specimens, the high grade sarcoma demonstrates malignant vasoformative morphology, as well as, strong diffuse staining with endothelial markers, consistent with a high grade angiosarcoma.
Sarcoma is present at margins.


DIAGNOSIS:
A. Para-caval mass: Favour residual mature teratoma with treatment effects. No evidence of malignant germ cell tumour, sarcoma or malignancy.

B. Peri-aortic tumour:
- Malignant vasoformative tumour, consistent with high grade angiosarcoma, present at margins.
- One of five lymph nodes shows direct invasion by angiosarcoma.
- Background nodular organised fibrosis and dystrophic calcification ?treatment related change.

C. Left retrocaval: Fibrosis and patchy mild non-specific chronic inflammation.

D. Right superior renal mass: 1.1mm focus of adrenal cortex on a background of multiple ganglia, fibrosis and inflammation. Seven reactive lymph nodes are present.

E. Anterior aortic tissue at renal vessels: Fibrosis and patchy mild non-specific chronic inflammation (0/1).

Pathology Report_
CLINICAL:
Para-rectal nodule. Uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes and ovaries. Pouch of douglas. Sigmoid serosal nodule. Omentum.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Para-rectal nodule&quot;, consists of tan tissue, 45 x 45 x up to 8mm. One surface is smooth and shiny with the appearance of cyst wall, and the other surface appears roughened. Serially sectioned perpendicular to the long axis. The cut surface shows the presumed cyst wall is up to 2mm thick. RS embedded in three blocks. Blocks 4 to 12 - remainder of nodule. AE.
B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes and ovaries&quot;, consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries weighing 103g in total.&#160; The uterus measures 58 x 90 x 40mm and the cervix measures 15 x 13mm. The serosal surface of the uterus is largely smooth and shiny, however there ris a nodule protruding from the posterior fundus, 22mm in maximum dimension. The cervix appears unremarkable. The right fallopian tube and ovary are adherent to the uterus, however, the right fallopian tube is approximately 50mm in length and 5mm in maximum diameter and the right ovary is approximately 20 x 10 x up to 10mm.  The left fallopian tube is 60mm in length and 4mm in maximum diameter.&#160; The left ovary measures 20 x 10 x 8mm. On sectioning, the endometrial aspect has a cystic appearance, 9mm in maximum thickness. The myometrium ranges from 8 to 36mm and shows a circumscribed yellow nodule with a somewhat lobulated cut surface, 25 x 20 x~20mm. There is also a fibroid, 33mm in maximum diameter. The previously described fundal nodule corresponds to a fibroid. Blocks: 1 to 4 - anterior sagittal section from uterus embedded from fundus to cervix; 5 to 8 - posterior sagittal section of uterus embedded from fundus to cervix; 9 &amp; 10 - RS yellow nodule; 11 to 14 - serial sections right fallopian tube; 15 to 22 - serial sections right ovary; 23 to 25 - serial sections left ovary; 26 to 30 - serial sections left fallopian tube; 31 - nodular structures and ?endometrium; 32 - subserosal pedunculated calcified fibroid with adjacent intra mural fibroid; 33 to 36 - composite sections uterus with endometrial nodule; 37 to 41 - composite sections uterus.

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Pouch of Douglas&quot;, consists of tan tissue, 20 x 8 x 5mm. Serially sectioned and AE in block C.
D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid serosal nodule&quot;, consists of four tan biopsies, 5 to 7mm. AE in block D.
E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of fatty tissue, 160 x 190 x 10mm. Multifocal nodules up to 4mm are identified. RS embedded in blocks E1 to E3.    (TO:LR/ta/ta 4/6/71)
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr R Rehder):
A. The specimen is entirely embedded and examined. Sections show dense fibrous tissue, a small amount of fibroadipose connective tissue and a small focus of ovarian tissue. In areas the fibrous tissue is surfaced mesothelium and there is patchy surface mesothelial surface reaction, subserosal fibrosis associated and subacute haemorrhage in the form of hemosiderin laden macrophages. A small focus of subserosal tumour is present (A7, A8). The tumour is composed of epitheloid cells with moderately pleomorphic round to oval nuclei, mostly conspicuous nucleoli and a small to moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. The tumour cells are arranged in a loosely cohesive aggregates associated with an infiltrative small lymphocytes. Gland formation and slit- like architecture is not seen. The morphological appearance is similar to those seen in the remaining specimens.

B. Sections of uterus show a focus of subserosal high grade serous carcinoma involving the subserosa of the anterior uterine body (B1). The morphology as described previously. The myometrium shows numerous fibroids including subserosal and calcified fibroids.
There is a benign endometrial polyp and the endometrium is otherwise inactive.

The ectocervix is unremarkable and uninvolved. The endocervix shows conspicuous Nabothian cysts.

The fallopian tubes are serially sectioned and entirely embedded and examined.
The ovaries are entirely embedded and examined. High grade serous carcinoma  multifocally involves the right ovarian serosa and subserosa as well as right paraovarian soft tissues (B16 to B22).  High grade serous carcinoma  also involves the serosa and subserosa of the left ovary (B23 to B25), the left fallopian tube and right fallopian tube  (eg B26, B30, B11 to B14). No evidence of serous intraepithelial carcinoma in situ (STIC) is seen. There is a probable small focus of endometriosis in the right ovary (B18).

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive: CK7, PAX 8, WT1, P53 (mutation pattern with diffuse strong expression), Ber-EP4, P16 (diffuse), ER near diffuse strong, HBME-1 (patchy).
Negative: Calretinin, CK5/6, CK20, SATB2, CDX2.

The immunoprofile is consistent with high grade serous carcinoma.

C. The specimen is entirely embedded and examined. Sections show serosal lined fibrous tissue and fibromuscular tissue. There are patchy subserosal perivascular aggregates, however, no diagnostic tumour is seen. There is no significant fibrosis or subacute haemorrhage.

D. The sections show serosal lined fibrous tissue or fibromuscular tissue. There is extensive involvement by high grade serous carcinoma with morphology as previously described.

E. Representative sections show high grade serous carcinoma present as both subsersoal discrete nodules and infiltrating fat with an associated desmoplastic reaction. The tumour cells are  arranged in loosely cohesive aggregates or small solid nests with an associated lymphoid infiltrate.

COMMENT:
A to E. The morphology and immunoprofile are those of residual high serous carcinoma. Residual carcinoma focally involves the pararectal tissue and uterine subserosa with more extensive involvement of the serosa and subserosa of the fallopian tubes bilaterally (R &gt; L) and  ovaries bilaterally (R  &gt; L). There is also nodular tumour within the omentum. Serous intraepithelial tubular carcinoma in situ (STIC) of the fallopian tubes is not identified and the distribution of disease in the ovaries is predominately serosal and subserosal.

Chemotherapy Response Score (CRS)
Score 2:  Partial tumour response (regression associated fibro-inflammatory changes with readily identifiable viable tumour).


DIAGNOSIS:
A. To E. Pararectal nodule, uterus cervix bilateral fallopian tubes and bilateral ovaries: pouch of douglas, sigmoid serosal nodule, and omentum:
-  Residual high grade serous carcinoma involving pararectal tissue, uterine subserosa, bilateral fallopian tube serosa/subserosa, bilateral ovaries serosa/subserosa and omentum
-  Partial chemotherapy response (grade 2)
-  Pouch of Douglas uninvolved
-  Benign endometrial polyp, inactive endometrium, multiple fibroids, focal probable endometrosis right ovary.
Selected slides shown to Dr R Barcroft who concurs.

Specimen_type: Fresh Tissue
Pathology ReportCLINICAL:
Left axillary dissection level 3. 1. Level 1-3. 2. Level 3 nodes. Sarcomatoid lesions - previous sarcoma + melanoma + colon cancer.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left axillary dissection&quot;, consists of an axillary dissection 125 x 87 x 68mm with an overlying ellipse of skin 72 x 11mm. Thirteen lymph nodes which range in size from 5-34mm are identified. 25mm deep to the skin is a tan nodule 80 x 75 x 53mm. At one end of the nodule is a tan/yellow and possibly necrotic area 47 x 31 x 35mm across.
Block 1- four lymph nodes; 2- three lymph nodes; 3 - three lymph nodes; 4 - one lymph node; 5 - one lymph node bisected; 6 &amp; 7 - one lymph node trisected; 8-19 - composite section of nodule to skin; 20 - reserve block for biobanking. Photos taken.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Level 3 tissue&quot;, consists of two pieces of fibrofatty tissue 9-30mm across. Three lymph nodes which range in size from 5-10mm are seen. Block 1- three lymph nodes.
(TO:YL/ec 18/4/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr Z Reiner)
A. Sections show an 80mm deposit of metastatic undifferentiated (poorly differentiated) malignancy. The tumour consists of infiltrative sheets of poorly differentiated malignant cells with variable epithelioid to spindled morphology. The epithelioid appearing tumour cells have mild to moderate amounts of eosinophilic (focally rhabdoid) cytoplasm. The tumour cell nuclei appear epithelioid to spindled with moderate pleomorphism, round to angulated irregular nuclear membranes and hyperchromasia. Nuclei overlap and touch in areas. In block A16, a focus of markedly atypical bizarre epithelioid tumour cells is seen. Mitoses are readily identified throughout and there are broad sheets and serpiginous foci of tumour necrosis and haemorrhage (with focal dystrophic calcification and scattered cholesterol clefts). Tumour sheets appear separated by variably thick fibrous septae and whilst there are infiltrative foci that extend directly into adipose tissue, much of the tumour deposit appears surrounded by a fibrous pseudocapsule. Whilst the tumour deposit is a presumed lymph node metastasis, underlying nodal tissue is essentially completely effaced. Tumour is at least 0.45mm from the surgical margin (A19). The overlying skin shows no significant abnormality. One separate lymph node shows effacement by necrosis (without involvement by tumour) and eighteen additional lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy (0/18).

Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the results are as follows:
Tumour cells positive for: CAM5.2 (perinuclear dot like), desmin (perinuclear dot like), CD56, BCL-6
Tumour cells negative for: S100, SOX10, synaptophysin, STAT6, CK20, chromogranin, MITF, MIC2, SMA, LCA, CD34, HMB45, MelanA and BCL-6.
A ki-67 is high (greater than 80%).
Additional stains performed in 2070 not repeated.


COMMENT:
The 80mm left axillary tumour is a deposit of metastatic (high grade) poorly differentiated malignancy.

The previous history is noted:
- 2002: External slides reviewed at CONDOBOLIN RETIREMENT VILLAGE (ZM-64-317032) of right upper arm subcutaneous lump which was diagnosed as a monophasic synovial sarcoma.
- 2013: Skin lesion excised from back and the tissue is examined at HAWKER MEMORIAL HOSPITAL (ZM-64-317032). A diagnosis of superficial spreading melanoma (Breslow thickness 0.5 mm, Clark level III) with a predominance of naevoid cells was made.
- 2017: Subtotal colectomy at TOTTENHAM HOSPITAL (94P43170) for caecal adenocarcinoma, pT3 N1a Mx R0.
- 2018: Liver segmental resection at LONG JETTY HEALTH CARE FACILITY (94P43170) for metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with colorectal primary.
- 2020: Left axillary and right femoral reaming biopsies: Poorly differentiated malignancy with necrosis; variable cytokeratin, SOX10, S100 positivity; SSYT negative - favour metastatic melanoma, cannot exclude metastatic sarcoma or sarcomatoid carcinoma.

The previous left axillary and right femoral reaming biopsies have been reviewed and show overlapping histopathologic features and morphologic similarity to the current 80mm left axillary lesion. Whilst no demonstrable SOX10 or S100 staining is seen in this current excision, there is persisting positive cytokeratin, desmin and CD56 staining. BRAF, CK14, GFAP and K3K27me3 remain outstanding (other stains performed in 2070 have not been repeated).

Overall, the 80mm left axillary deposit is a poorly differentiated high grade malignancy. Whilst there are similarities in morphology between the recently reported left axillary biopsy, femoral reaming biopsy and this current left axillary excision, there are some differences in the overall pattern of immunohistochemical staining in the tumours, making definitive classification difficult. However, following intra-departmental review, an overall pathologic differential diagnosis is thought to include: a dedifferentiated malignant melanoma; poorly differentiated carcinoma/neuroendocrine carcinoma; poorly differentiated myoepithelial carcinoma, as well as, a malignant sarcomatoid tumour (eg. MPNST). Given that classification of this tumour is difficult and there remains some uncertainy, the case (and previous biopsies from 2070) will be sent to Professor DYLAN RASHID for an additional opinion.

B. Sections of the three level three lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy (0/3).


DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left axillary dissection:
- 80mm deposit of poorly differentiated malignancy (difficult to subclassify and sent for additional opinion from Professor Pat).
- One additional lymph node effaced by necrosis only and 18 reactive appearing lymph nodes.
- Margin appears clear of tumour (0.45mm).

B. Level 3 tissue: No evidence of malignancy.

MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Right gluteal tumour&quot;, consists of a circumscribed tan, smooth and shiny tissue with attached muscle and fatty tissue, 150 x 110 x 90mm. Three long sutures noted as well as smaller non-orientating sutures holding the muscles together as per the surgeon. Superficially the muscles are retracted and reveal a false margin. Inking: black - deep margin, blue - superficial margin, green - deep resection margin, red - superficial false margin, yellow - lateral margin. On sectioning the cut surface shows a pale and multicystic structure with two large cysts up to 80mm in diameter. The cyst wall thickness ranges from 2-5mm. The two larger cysts contain clear serous fluid. The specimen is serially sliced from superior to inferior into eighteen slices. Please see diagrams &amp; photos. Specimen shown to Dr N Lindow.
Block 1&amp; 2 - LS of superficial margin; 3- superficial margin with cyst wall abutting the surface; 4 - lateral margin; 5 - part of cyst wall muscle and superficial margin; 6 - lateral margin; 7 - medial margin; 8 - lateral margin; 9 - superficial margin with muscles; 10 - superficial margin with muscle and part of cyst; 11 - medial margin and part of cyst wall; 12 &amp; 13 - part of cyst wall; 14 - superficial margin with muscle and part of cyst wall; 15 - part of cyst; 16 - part of cyst wall from the lateral margin; 17 - part of the cyst wall from the superficial margin; 18 &amp; 19 - deep resection margin; 20-22 - LS of deep margin. (Blocks 9, 10, 17 contain part of the false superficial margin). RS. (TO:DN/ec 5/4/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr N Dellasciucca):
Sections show a well circumscribed hypocellular myxoid lesion.  The tumour is composed of bland spindle cells surrounded by abundant myxoid stroma.  The slender spindle cells are relatively uniform with no significant cytological atypia or mitotic activity.  The cellularity of lesion is relatively evenly distributed and the cellularity appears to be higher than usual myxoma.  The periphery is slightly more cellular with collagenized capsule.  At periphery, the tumour infiltrates into the surrounding striated muscle.  No lipoblasts are seen.  There is scant blood vessels.  The matrix is slightly basophilic matrix with a few mucinous cysts.  The spindle cells are positive for CD34 and Vimentin.  The stains for S100, SOX10, EMA, SMA, Desmin, Myogenin, MUC4 and ALK are negative.  The overall appearances are consistent with those of intramuscular myxoma.  Because of the increased cellularity, the tumour is best to be classified as a cellular myxoma.  The tumour is completely excised.  In several locations, the tumour is separated from the resection margin by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.
DIAGNOSIS:
Right gluteal tumour - Cellular myxoma (intramuscular).

MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr B Landry):
A. The oriented excision of markedly sun damaged skin to subcutis and skeletal muscle shows residual incompletely excised High grade sarcoma adjacent to a scar.

The tumour is located mostly in the deep aspect of the specimen tracking within the skeletal muscle and deep to the subcutis within fascia like dense fibrous tissue and focally extends into the dermis.

There is a variable appearance of the tumour. In most areas there is a more exansile circumscribed high grade component. It is moderate to marked cellular with a spindled to epithelioid appearance. The nuclear are irregular in shape, hyprochromatic and without any nucleoli. Mitoses including atypical forms are easily identified (38 mitoses/10HPF). There are widespread intermixed osteoclastic-type giant cells, haemorrhage and hemosiderophages in between the atypical tumour cells. Some geographic necrosis is present.

There is also a more low grade component lacking the osteoclastic giant cells and comprises more mildly to moderately atypical single spindle cells (13, 16 -22, 25).These neoplastic atypical cells track widely beyond the expansile high grade nodules along the fibrous septa. Focal haemosiderin is associated with it.

The morpholgy is similar to the previous excision (00I57282). At that time the tumour showed also a heterogeneous appearance. In the current excision there are also occasional mildly atypical stromal cells which at times are difficult to distinguish between neoplastic and reactive due to adjuvant therapy. No immunohistochemistry has been repeated.

There is no lymphovascular invasion and a couple of nerves are overrun, however no convincing perineural invasion is seen.

The high grade component with the multinucleated giant cell extends broadly towards the deep margin in numerous sections examined including up to the edge to the 9 o&apos;clock peripheral margin (9). The 6 o&apos;clock peripheral margin is involved by the low grade component (24, 25). The more superficial peripheral 12 o&apos;clock, 3 o&apos;clock and 9 o&apos;clock margins appears clear by at least 5mm.

B. The representative sections of bone show widespread tumour in between the trabeculae resembling the osteoclast like giant cell rich high grade component from specimen A. It extends to the margin.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left para-spinal resection, oriented excision: High grade sarcoma, margins involved.

B. Occipital bone hole at left: High grade Sarcoma extending to margin. Additional sections to follow.

Pathology ReportCLINICAL:
Previous hysterectomy, no evidence of ovaries. Large pelvic mass. Normal Ca 125. General clinical history:  polymicrogyria exercise tolerance. Ex-smoker. Type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolaemia, hypertension.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Pelvic cyst&quot;, consists of an opened cystic mass, 90 x 70 x 40mm, with detached pale to tan tissue fragments, 50 x 40 x 20mm in aggregate.  The outer surface appears dull, fibrous and haemorrhagic. No fallopian tube or normal ovary is identified.  The outer surface of the specimen is inked in blue. On section, the cut surface shows a solid cystic structure with clear serous fluid and also chocolate brown fluid. Blocks: 1 to 10 - RS cystic mass; 11 - RS  detached tissue ?blood clot  ?fibrin; 12 - for Biobank.  RS. Shown to Dr T Kahoohalphala.
B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of a fatty tissue, 65 x 55 x 15mm. No nodule is found. Representative embedded into three blocks. RS.   (TO:DN/ta 27/5/71)
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr T Wellington and registrar Dr T Brucie):


A. The sections show fibrofatty tissue with a clear cell carcinoma. The tumour show papillary, acinar and solid architectural patterns and is composed of malignant cells with clear and eosinophilic cytoplasm and areas showing marked cytologic atypia. Mitotic figures are readily identified. Small (&lt; 10%) areas of necrotic tumour are noted (e.g., slide A12).  There is patchy endometriosis adjacent to the tumour (slides A2, A5, A7). The tumour appears clear of the inked margins, but macrophages and mesothelial cells are seen in one area (slide A10), confirmed with calretinin and CD68 immunoperoxidase stains. The detached fragments show blood clot.

Immunohistochemistry shows patchy expression of Napsin A antigen in the tumour cells. WT1 antigen is not expressed in the tumour cells. There is focal, very weak expression of oestrogen receptor antigen in the tumour cells.  Progesterone receptor antigen is not expressed.


Mismatch Repair Deficiency (MMRD) Status
MLH1		Preserved nuclear staining
PMS2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH6		Preserved nuclear staining

Comment:
Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

B. The sections show lobulated mature adipose tissue consistent with omentum.  Patchy chronic inflammation is seen.  No evidence of malignancy is found in representative sections.


DIAGNOSIS:
A. Pelvic cyst:
- Clear cell carcinoma.
B. Omentum:
- No significant abnormality.

Site_name: YARRAWONGA HEALTH
Facility_id: 016
Specimen_type: Fresh Tissue
Pathology ReportCLINICAL:
Left posterior arm excision. Core bx - malignant. Peripheral nerve sheath tumour. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy.


MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Left posterior arm sarcoma&quot; received fresh, oriented with Surgeon and Dr I Duartes present. Sample taken for Biobank. Specimen consists of an ellipse of skin, 170 x 40mm to a depth of 75mm. There is one suture indicating proximal as per surgeon, designated superior. Medial blue, lateral black. The specimen is serially sectioned from superior to inferior into thirteen slices. On sectioning there is a well circumscribed, lobulated fatty mass, 125 x 110 x 70mm, with attached fatty and muscular tissue. There is a central 70 x 50 x 40mm tumour cavity filled with yellow serous fluid. Blocks: 1 - LS slice one; 2 - RS slice five; 3 &amp; 4 - RS slice six; 5 - RS slice seven; 6 - RS slice eight; 7 - RS slice seven; 8 - RS slice eight; 9 - RS slice nine; 10 - RS slice ten; 11 - RS slice seven; 12 &amp; 13 - RS slice eight; 14 - RS slice ten; 15 - RS slice twelve; 16 &amp; 17 - LS slice thirteen; 18 - RS slice six, showing interface of skin to tumour; 19 to 24 - RS showing tumour from slices four, five, seven, eight, nine and ten; 25 - for Biobank. RS. Shown to Dr I Bergren. Please see diagrams.  (TO:DN/ta 27/5/71)
MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr I Taub &amp; Dr I Boerger)
Sections of the 170mm left posterior arm lesion show a malignant spindle cell sarcoma. The tumour has a predominant pushing advancing edge with a variably thick fibrous pseudocapsule. There is a surrounding cuff of mature fibradipose tissue and skeletal muscle. The tumour is moderately to highly cellular and is composed of malignant plump to anaplastic spindled cells arranged in herringbone and peritheliomatous patterns. At the centre of the lesion, there is extensive suppurative necrosis (with up to 85% of tumour appearing necrotic). Up to 16 mitoses per 10 hpf are seen. At the interface between viable and necrotic tumour, the tumour appears less cellular with a haphazard arrangement of the malignant spindled cells. The residual tumour shows features consistent with previous treatment (fibrinoid necrosis of vessels with superimposed myxohyaline change, inflammation and extensive necrosis as previously described). The overlying shows reactive changes.

The margins of excision are as follows:
Proximal: Clear of tumour (at least 10mm) (1)
Distal: 3.3mm (16)
Medial: 4mm (2)
Lateral: 3.3mm (12)
Deep: 5mm (7)
Superficial (distal end - no overlying skin): 2.2mm (15)


IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY:
Tumour cells positive for: Pancytokeratin (focal ?aberrant), P40 (focal ?aberrant), CD34 (patchy cytoplasmic staining).
Tumour cells negative for: TLE1 (focal non-specific), CAM5.2, CD31, STAT6, myogenin, desmin (focal non-specific), CD99 (non-specific), SMA, S100 and SOX10.
H3K27me3 shows loss of nuclear staining in most tumour cells (&gt;85%).


COMMENT:
The 170mm posterior arm lesion is a high grade spindled/sarcomatoid malignancy. The appearance is similar to that described in the recent core biopsy (DHM 14171-21MP Dr Scheel) including loss of H3K27me3. However, no demonstrable S100, SOX10 or smooth/skeletal muscle staining is seen.

Overall, the findings support the original preferred diagnosis of a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. There is no definitive rhabdomyosarcomatous differentiation.

Grading of sarcomas may not be reliable after treatment, however, in the material examined the overall features would be in keeping with FNCLCC grade 3 (high grade).
(Tumour score = 3; mitosis score = 2; necrosis = 2; total score = 7/8).


DIAGNOSIS:
Left posterior arm: 170mm high grade spindled/sarcomatoid malignancy, clear of margins (see comment).

MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left mass groin stitch long lateral, short superior&quot;, consists of an ellipse excision of skin, 105mm (superior to inferior) by 80mm (medial to lateral) by 43mm (superficial to deep). Two sutures are present as described. In addition, there is one smaller suture on the lateral aspect and two on the deep aspect, reconstituting the margin as described. Lateral inked blue, medial inked green and deep inked black. Specimen is sectioned from superior to inferior into six slices. In the centre of the excision is a tan circumscribed and gelatinous lesion, 55 x 45 x 43mm. The lesion is 13mm deep to the skin, 9mm from the medial margin and encased by a thin fibrous layer on the lateral aspect less than 1mm thick. There are no areas of necrosis within the lesion. Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - LS superior end; 3 - close tumour to skin; 4 - lateral margin; 5 &amp; 6 - deep margin; 7 - medial margin; 8 - lateral margin; 9 &amp; 10 - deep margin; 11 - medial margin; 12 &amp; 13 - composite skin to tumour; 14 - central tumour; 15 &amp; 16 - LS inferior end; 17 - reserve for Biobanking. Diagram available.
B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Lateral deep margin left mass groin stitch on the margin&quot;, consists of a tan piece of tissue, 30 x 12 x 3mm. A suture is present on one side as described. Sutured side inked blue, opposite side inked black. Serially sectioned AE 3 blocks.  (TO:YL/ta 28/5/71)
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr N Captain):
A. Sections show fibrous tissue and fat with a circumscribed atypical spindle cell lesion. The lesion is moderately cellular, and is composed of spindle shaped tumour cells with elongated, plump, hyperchromatic nuclei, within myxoid stroma. Thin walled vessels are seen in the background. Scattered  tumour cells with large pleomorphic nuclei are seen. Tumour cells with intracytoplasmic vacuoles displacing the nuclei and occasional mitoses are seen. No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is present.

Positive staining is seen for EMA, CD34, and SMA. Patchy staining is seen for S100. Rare cells show positive staining for neurofilament. SOX10 (performed twice) is negative. PanCK, desmin, melan A, desmin, MUC4, CD99, GLUT1, TLE1, HMB45, stat-6 and c-kit are negative. INI-1 and H3K27me3 are retained. Ki67 index is approx. 1%.

Margins:
Lateral: 1mm (A9)
Medial: 5mm (A11)
Deep: positive over a 3mm front (A5)
Other margins: &gt; 10mm

COMMENT
The findings are of a low grade myxoid spindle cell lesion. There is positive staining for EMA and patchy staining for S100. A perineurioma is favoured over a neurofibroma or cellular angiofibroma. MDM2/DDIT3 FISH testing will be performed at KAPUNDA HOSPITALt&apos;s Hospital, MURWILLUMBAH, to exclude myxoid liposarcoma and low grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

The case will be sent to Prof DERRICK RIVINIUS, North Pathology, for external review.

B. Sections show dense fibrous tissue with no evidence of malignancy.


DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left groin mass: low grade myxoid spindle cell lesion (see comment)
B. Deep margin: no evidence of malignancy
ADDITIONAL REPORT (17/6/71)
MDM2 FISH showed no evidence of amplification (see attached report). DDIT3 FISH probe is no longer available at MUNGINDI HOSPITAL&apos;s Hospital, ANNA BAY.

The case also discussed with Prof JARROD ADIL. EWSR FISH is recommended to exclude myoepithelioma.

Tissue will be sent to PORT AUGUSTA HOSPITAL Hospital for EWSR and DDIT3 FISH testing.


ADDITIONAL REPORT (29/6/71)
There is no evidence of EWSR or DDIT3 rearrangement to suggest myoepithelioma or myxoid liposarcoma.

The case has been reviewed by Prof MILFORD WALSTRUM, Med Onc Pathology. The findings are of a low grade myxoid spindle cell lesion, and a cellular angiofibroma is favoured.


FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left groin mass: low grade myxoid spindle cell lesion, favour cellular angiofibroma
B. Deep margin: no evidence of malignancy

MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr E Wiebusch):
RHABDOMYOSARCOMA SYNOPTIC REPORT (BIOPSY)
Morphologic description:
The tumour is located in the subcutis up to the interface with muscle and is mildly infiltrative without capsule and some entrapment of surrounding adipocytes. There is a moderately to variable markedly cellular spindled to epithelioid/rhabdoid cell proliferation with scattered osteoclastic type and tumour giant cells. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic but no unequivocal striation is seen. There appears to be a variable abrupt transition from lower to widespread higher grade/pleomorphic areas (best seen in 6). The nuclei show variation in size with mostly intermediate to scattered marked pleomorphism. The nuclei are ovoid with irregular nuclear membranes, some coarse chromatin and some show distinct nucleoli. There are areas of more prominent thick collagen bundles in between the tumour, hyalinisation and coagulative and infarct type necrosis. Florid mitotic activity is seen (31mitoses/10HPF with field diameter 0.55mm) including some atypical forms. The scattered single more prominent atypical cells (up to 3 times the size of the average tumour cell combined with atypical mitoses and the small circumscribed area of increased atypia are best regarded a focal areas of anaplasia.
The peripheral 9 o&apos;clock margin is best regarded as focally involved (3) at the level of subcutis and in another focus the 9 o&apos;clock margin is less than 0.1mm away (6). The 3 o&apos;clock peripheral margin is 4mm away.The deep margin is 1.6mm with an intact soft tissue plane (4). The other margins are further away.
The overlying skin shows moderate sun damage.

Immunohistochemistry:
The tumour cells are diffusely positive for desmin (cytoplasmic). SMA shows patchy positive staining. Myogenin (nuclear) shows scattered single and small aggregates of positive cells. INI-1 shows retained nuclear staining. EMA shows scattered single cells with rather membranous staining. Pancytokeratin shows scattered small aggregates of staining
The tumour cells are negative for ERG, Sox10 and S100.

The morphological and immunohistochemical features show some similarity to the previous description in the core biopsy report from DHM. In the outside core biopsy Myogenin and Pancytokeratin were negative in contrast to the current excision however this may represent sampling.

Comment: The features are those of a rhabdomyosarcoma with some spindled areas including tumour giant cells and some sclerosis associated with focal anaplasia. The features are favoured to represent spindle cell/sclerosing type with patchy areas of pleomorphism over pleomorphic subtype. Dr E Lindeen concurs.

See diagram.  (TO:YL/ec 29/10/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr M Kuligowski):
Sections show skin excised to include subcutaneous fat plus a small amount of underlying skeletal muscle. There is a lobulated and somewhat circumscribed cellular tumour centred in the subcutaneous fat. The tumour focally bulges into deep dermis. The superficial dermis, epidermis and skeletal muscle are uninvolved. The tumour is composed of compact fascicles of plump spindle cells with moderate amounts of lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei and one to two nucleoli. Mitotic figures are occasionally seen and focally number up to 4 per 10 HPF. Necrosis is not identified. There are moderate numbers of admixed inflammatory cells including lymphocytes, plasma cells and eosinophils within the tumour. The tumour also shows nodular areas of hyalinisation and myxoid change associated with foamy histiocytes and haemosiderin laden macrophages. These alteration is regarded as treatment related changes and is seen in approximately 60% of the tumour. No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is seen.

The tumour cells show the following immunoprofile:
-  Positive:  EMA.
-  Equivocal:  S100 (scattered tumour cells, no more than 5%) and Melan A (faint cytoplasmic staining in around 1% of tumour cells).
-  Negative:  MNF116, Cam5.2, CK5/6, SOX10, HMB45, MUM1, CD34, SMA, desmin, myogenin, STAT6, MUC4 and ALK.
Nuclear expression of H3K37m3 is retained.
The Ki-67 proliferation index is up to around 10% at hotspots by visual estimation.

The overall features are those of a malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.

The cellular tumour mass itself is 1 mm from the deep margin (Block 14). However, the tissue deep to the tumour has a paucicellular and loose myxoid appearance in which there are interspersed atypical cells . These cells may represent reactive atypia in benign stromal cells although tumour cells with treatment effect can show a similar cytology and as such, definite clearance of tumour at the deep margin cannot be guaranteed. This loose myxoid change is present at the deep margin over at least a 5 mm front (Blocks 13, 14 &amp; 15). The tumour mass and deep loose myxoid stromal change are &gt; 10 mm from all peripheral margins.


DIAGNOSIS:
Excision of lesion, right forearm (post radiotherapy):  Malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with treatment effect

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr Z Armson)
A.  Sections show squamous mucosa and underlying submucosa and muscularis propria. There is no evidence of malignancy.
B.  Sections show fragments of apparently subcapsular liver with fibrosis and chronic inflammation without fibrous tissue and bile ducts within fibrous tissue.  Negative for malignancy.
C.  Sections of both macroscopically identified tumour masses have similar morrphology.  The appearances are those of diffuse type gastric carcinoma (poorly cohesive carcinoma) including signet ring cells. There is a wide variation in the morphology of tumour cells including some with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, some with increased nucleus to cytoplasm ratio, some with vacuolated cytoplasm and some with targetoid intracytoplasmic inclusions. In addition there are foci of squamous differentiation identified including rare intercellular bridges and these are positive for CK5/6 and p-40. The squamous differentiation form less than 25% of the tumour volume (and hence does not fulfil criteria given by some authors for a diagnosis of adenosquamous carcinoma). The diffuse gastric carcinoma is positive for CK20 (strong diffuse), focal CK7, and strong diffuse E-cadherin.
There is prominent lymphatic vascular space invasion.
Both macroscopic tumour masses  involve the full thickness of the gastric wall to reach the adjacent serosa and with infiltration of the immediately adjacent greater omentum.  Sections of the stomach in between the two main tumour masses show lymphatic permeation by carcinoma as well as deposits of infiltrative carcinoma within the submucosa.  It is likely that one of the macroscopic tumour masses represents intragastric spread of the other tumour.
Carcinoma is 12mm from the proximal resection margin and is not seen in the sections from the distal resection margin.
There is patchy chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa. Giemsa stain is negative for Helicobacter. No intestinal metaplasia is seen in the sections examined.
8 of 8 lesser curve lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma.
8 of 8 greater curve lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma.
4 of 4 splenic hilar lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma.
Sections of the spleen are unremarkable and sections of the pancreas are unremarkable.
Sections of the fallopian tubes and ovaries are unremarkable.  Sections of the separate pieces of peritoneum are unremarkable.
D.  The sections show squamous mucosa and small intestinal mucosa and underlying muscularis propria.  Negative for malignant cells.
E.  The sections show skin with underlying fibrofatty tissue and shows fibroblastic reaction, birefringent foreign material and fibroblastic reaction and patchy chronic inflammation consistent with effects of previous surgery.  Negative for malignancy.

CLINICAL:
Left radical orchidectomy.  Liposarcoma of spermatic cord.  Previous inguinal hernia repair.  Overlying scrotal skin - suture is cord.  Deep surface superiorly near cord suture is external oblique aponeurosis.


MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Re-excision sarcoma left groin/scrotum, stitch on cord&quot;, consists of a 160 x 82 x 40mm radical orchidectomy.  There is a 105 x 82mm overlying triangular excision of skin with a 31mm vertical bilateral iatrogenic linear defect.  A suture is present as described.  Medial inked blue, lateral inked green, deep inked black, cord inked yellow.  Sampled for biobank.  Shave of spermatic cord taken and false margin inked red.  The specimen is serially sliced (superior to inferior) into fifteen slices.  The testicle is seen in slices fourteen and fifteen measuring 25 x 30 x 25mm.  On sectioning there is a haemorrhagic cavity seen in slices eleven to thirteen, 25 x 15 x 30mm.  Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - shave of spermatic cord; 3 &amp; 4 - deeper shave of spermatic cord; 5 to 16 - LS slice one; 17 to 20 - composite slice three; 21 to 24 - composite slice five; 25 to 29 - composite slice seven; 30 to 35 - composite slice nine; 36 to 40 - composite slice ten; 41 to 45 - composite slice eleven; 47 to 50 - composite slice twelve; 51 to 54 - composite slice thirteen; 55 to 62 - LS slice fifteen; 63 - ? haematoma.  Shown to Dr N Skartvedt.  Photograph available.  (TO:DN/ta 15/10/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr N Sacchi):
Sections show skin with underlying testis and surrounding fatty tissue.  The testis shows Leydig cell hyperplasia and age-related changes.  There is a region of fibrosis associated with an organising haematoma and focal haemosiderin deposition in keeping with previous surgery.  In addition, there are small numbers of dispersed atypical spindle to stellate cells with enlarged hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei.  These atypical cells are seen throughout the entirety of the specimen.  The background stroma has a fibrous to myxoid appearance.  In areas, the adipocytes show a mild degree of variation in cell sizes.  The histology is consistent with a well-differentiated liposarcoma with mixed lipoma-like and sclerosing features.

The atypical cells extends to the spermatic cord shave margin as well as the deep margin focally.  Assessment of clearance amongst the rest of the margins is difficult due to the subtle cell size variation amongst the adipocytes and the sparsely distributed nature of the atypical cells.  Recognising this limitation, the excision margins are summarised as follows:
-  Spermatic cord margin:  Involved by tumour (Block 1).
-  Superficial:  3 mm (Block 27).
-  Deep:  Involved by tumour (Block 19).
-  Superior:  &gt; 10 mm.
-  Inferior:  6 mm (Block 55).
-  Medial:  1 mm (Blocks 41 &amp; 42).
-  Lateral:  2 mm (Blocks 39 &amp; 50).
The overlying skin is uninvolved.  Two reactive lymph nodes are identified.

There is no evidence of dedifferentiation.

Reserve block for molecular studies:  42.
Reserve block for tumour banking:  39.


DIAGNOSIS:
Left groin/scrotum:  Consistent with well-differentiated liposarcoma

Comment:  Material will be forwarded to ST GEORGE'S HEALTH SERVICE Hospital for confirmatory MDM2 FISH testing.

The circumference of the stomach is 110mm.  4mm of tissue at the proximal and distal end of the stomach are sacrificed in removing staples.  The proximal margin is inked blue, and the distal margin is inked black.  The serosa shows a bulge however, no perforation is identified. Histology shows  both segments of small bowel and a segment of colon to contain deposits of metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma which lie within the muscularis propria and serosa of the specimens. The tumour deposits are characterised by abundant extracellular mucin with numerous small nests and acini formed by cells with mild to moderate nuclear atypia and features reminiscent of goblet cell carcinoid. However Ki67 is high at &gt;80% which is way beyond that acceptable for goblet cell carcinoid and therefore the current deposits are best considered as moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma. Some pieces of skin with underlying scarred dermis and associated fat are also present which are not infiltrated by malignancy. The gallbladder shows mild cholesterolosis of the mucosa with no serosal deposits present.  The cystic duct lymph node is not involved by malignancy.

RECTUM, SMALL BOWEL, OMENTUM, GALLBLADDER, COLON, PERITONEAL DISEASE-

&quot;COLON AND PERITONEAL DISEASE&quot;.
Colectomy - a colectomy measuring  up to 420mm in length with multiple gelatinous tumour deposits across the length. At one end there is an anastomosis present. On opening the mucosa shows focal ulceration, no polyps or tumour seen. On sectioning the area of focal ulceration mid length there is a gelatinous tumour protruding into the lumen measuring 10mm.

(1 RS anastomosis; 2-5 RS serosal tumour deposits; 6 ulcerated mucosa).

Peritoneal disease - Multiple fragments of peritoneum and gelatinous tumour measuring in aggregate 100x100x70mm. Adherent to one piece of peritoneum there is an irregular skin excision 45x30mm (umbilicus). On sectioning there are multiple cystic spaces with gelatinous tumour.

MICROSCOPIC:     (Dr. B Bourget)
Sections of the colectomy specimen show multiple serosal deposits of low to intermediate grade mucinous neoplasm. These deposits take the form of strips of mucinous epitheliumwhich in most areas show low-grade nuclear features. In some areas, there are  intermediate nuclear features, including nuclear hyperchromasia, focal pseudeostratification, prominent nucleoli, and occasional mitotic figures. Architecture is simple, with a few papillae seen focally, but no cribriform architecture. There are multiple deposits of extracellular mucin containing strips of low to intermediate grade mucinous epithelium on the peritoneal surface. At the area of macroscopically ulcerated mucosa, similar tumour is seen within the mucosa and submucosa, with focal ulceration. A few foci of desmoplastic stromal reaction are seen in response to foci of atypical epithelium and a few irregular glands. In the sections of skin, mucinous tumour is seen within the dermis and subcutis (Block 7). Sections of the bowel wall on either side of the anastomosis show viable small intestine and colonic wall. Sections of the long segment of bowel wall show serosal deposits of low to intermediate grade mucinous tumour. Two small lymph nodes show no involvement.
Comment: The most likely primary site would be appendix, however many other primary sites are possible, and clinical correlation is required.

DIAGNOSIS:
COLON AND PERITONEAL DISEASE:
- MULTIFOCAL, PREDOMINANTLY PERITONEAL INVOLVEMENT BY LOW TO INTERMEDIATE GRADE MUCINOUS NEOPLASM. CLINICAL CORRELATION IS REQUIRED (PLEASE SEE TEXT).

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT:

CLINICAL:
79yo F. Ovarian Ca. Debulking OT. Additional history: previous core favoured High grade serous carcinoma, had adjuvant therapy


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left fallopian tube + ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and a solid cystic ovarian mass, 55 x 45 x 30mm. The mass is adherent to the fallopian tube and has a smooth outer surface with some roughened areas. The cut surface shows a uniloculated cyst with papillary and solid areas. The solid area makes up approximately 20% of the mass. Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - fallopian tube with adherent ovarian mass; 3 to 10 - RS ovarian mass; 11 - biobank. RS. Shown to Dr G Rademaker.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right tube + ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and ovary with attached ligament, 50 x 40 x 20mm. The fallopian tube is 60mm in length and up to 8mm in maximum diameter. There is a solid cystic mass, 10 x 7 x 6mm attached to the fallopian tube. The ovary measures 20 x 12 x 10mm. There is also another solid cystic lesion, 8 x 10 x 5mm attached to the ovary. The ovary has an unremarkable cut surface. Shown to Dr G Petruzzi. Blocks: 1 to 8 - fallopian tube and ovary. RS.

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right round ligament&quot;, consists of a tan to haemorrhagic nodular piece of tissue, 20 x 15 x 8mm. Sectioned and AE 2 blocks.

D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right uterosacral&quot;, consists of a fragment of ligament and attached solid cystic mass, 40 x 20 x 18mm. The attached solid cystic mass is 25 x 20 x 15mm. Serially sectioned and AE 6 blocks.

E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right rectal mass&quot;, consists of multiple fragments of friable, tan and fatty tissue, 90 x 65 x 30mm in aggregate. Shown to Dr G Harries. Unable to identify rectum in specimen. There are areas of haemorrhage but no obvious necrosis seen. Blocks: 1 to 4 - one almost complete face of tumour; 5 to 9 - further RS mass. RS.

F.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal tumour&quot;, consists of an irregular tan and haemorrhagic piece of tissue with attached adipose tissue, 60 x 20 x 18mm. Cut surface shows solid and papillary areas. Serially sectioned and AE 6 blocks.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left rectal nodule&quot;, consists of a multinodular tan tissue with attached adipose tissue, 32 x 20 x 10mm. The cut surface is pale, firm and nodular. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

H.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal mesentery&quot;, consists of an irregular tan and haemorrhagic piece of tissue, with attached adipose tissue, 30 x 20 x 13mm. Serially sliced and AE 2 blocks.

I.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid nodule&quot;, consists of a tan and haemorrhagic nodule with attached adipose tissue, 33 x 25 x 20mm. The nodule has a rough outer surface, and the cut surface shows a pale and uniform cut surface. Serially sectioned and AE 5 blocks. RS.

J.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid mesentery&quot;, consists of tan and haemorrhagic fibrofatty tissue, 23 x 15 x 8mm. Sectioned and AE 1 block.

K.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid epiploic&quot;, consists of a piece of fatty tissue with attache tan nodule, 33 x 20 x 10mm. There are multiple pale to tan nodules attached ranging from 3 to 10mm in maximum diameter. Serially sectioned AE 2 blocks.

L.  Specimen labelled &quot;Bladder nodule&quot;, consists of a fibrous piece of tissue with attached multinodular mass, 35 x 18 x 13mm. There is a multicystic mass measuring 10 x 6 x 7mm attached. Resection margin inked. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

M.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right common iliac lymph node&quot;, consists of haemorrhagic and fatty piece of tissue, 35 x 20 x 15mm. On sectioning, there does not appear to be a normal lymph node and appears to be a solid cystic nodule with about 50% of the nodule being solid and the solid areas also contain papillary areas as well. Shown to Dr G Halcomb. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

N.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of a piece of fatty tissue with attached multiple solid cystic masses 340 x 340 x 45mm in total. There are up to nine solid cystic masses ranging from 25mm to 85mm in maximum diameter. The cut surface of the larger mass appears to be cystic and solid areas with necrosis. Shown to Dr G Kyhn. Blocks: 1 to 10 - RS solid cystic mass. RS.
(TO:DN/ta 3/5/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr G Susla):
A. The left fallopian tube and ovary are widely replaced by High grade Serous carcinoma showing no convincing response to adjuvant therapy.

It is characterised by widely cystic papillary appearance with areas of more solid and micropapillary appearance and in other areas the tumour tracks through stroma associated with a desmoplastic reaction. Scattered calcifications are seen. The tumour shows variable pleomorphism including marked atypical cells and nucleoli. The fimbrial end is lined partially by tumour cells resembling the carcinoma in keeping with fallopian tube origin.

The ovary shows a corpus albicans.

Immunohistochemistry:
Pax8: diffusely positive
P53: patchy positive
WT1: widespread strong positive
CA125: widespread positive
ER: widespread positive
PR: negative
CK7: widespread positive
CK20: negative

B. The right ovary is involved by the carcinoma. Some mesothelial inclusion cysts and corpora albicantes are noted. The fallopian tube shows no in situ component.

C. The right round ligament is widely involved by carcinoma.

D. The right uterosacral fibrous tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

E. The right rectal tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

F. The rectal fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma. A focus is suspicious for lymphovascular invasion. An unremarkable lymph node is included (0/1).

G. The left rectal fibrofatty tissue is widely involved by carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion is present.

H. The rectal mesentery fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

I. The sigmoid fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma and extends into one lymph node (1/1).

J. The sigmoid mesentery fibrofatty tissue is widely involved by carcinoma.

K. The sigmoid epiploic fibrofatty tissue is involved by carcinoma.

L. The bladder nodule shows fibrofatty tissue and some columnar mucosa and is involved by carcinoma.

M. The right common iliac lymph node is widely replaced by carcinoma (1/1). The deposit is at least 14mm across and no convincing extranodal extension is seen.

N. The omental fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left fallopian tube + ovary: High grade Serous carcinoma.

B. Right tube + ovary: High grade Serous carcinoma.

C. Right round ligament: High grade Serous carcinoma.

D. Right uterosacral: High grade Serous carcinoma.

E. Right rectal mass: High grade Serous carcinoma.

F. Rectal tumour: High grade Serous carcinoma.

G. Left rectal nodule: High grade Serous carcinoma.

H. Rectal mesentery: High grade Serous carcinoma.

I. Sigmoid nodule: High grade Serous carcinoma including one involved lymph node.

J. Sigmoid mesentery: High grade Serous carcinoma.

K. Sigmoid epiploic: High grade Serous carcinoma.

L. Bladder nodule: High grade Serous carcinoma.

M. Right common iliac lymph node: High grade Serous carcinoma in one lymph node.

N. Omentum: High grade Serous carcinoma.


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (6/7/2071):
P53 staining is variable in the tumour with some areas showing 80% strong expression and some areas show occasional mild and some wider areas no expression of p53. The features would be in keeping with mutation type p53 expression.

MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by DrJ Horman)
A.  Paraffin embedded sections of the left external iliac lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).
B.  Sections of the endometrial tumour show a mixed clear cell and endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma. The clear cell component comprises approximately two thirds of the tumour and consists of atypical clear cells with hobnailing overlying hyalinsed stromal cores (grade 3). The endometrioid adenocarcinoma consists predominantly of complex, crowded glands with villoglandular and cribriform architecture and minimal intervening stroma lined by moderately to highly pleomorphic carcinoma cells (FIGO architecture grade 1; nuclear grade 3 = endometrioid grade 2). Although much of the carcinoma is exophytic with broad areas of tumour associated necrosis, in areas, nests of carcinoma cells invade into myometrium to a depth of 2.2mm into a uterine wall 5.5mm thick. There is multifocal lymphovascular space invasion. There is no evidence of serosal surface involvement.

B.  Uterus, cervix, tubes and ovaries:
Mixed clear cell and endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma.
Carcinoma invades to a depth of 2.2mm into a uterine wall 5.5mm thick.
There is multifocal lymphovascular space invasion.
Cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries show no significant abnormality.

C.  Right external iliac lymph nodes: No evidence of malignancy in three lymph nodes (0/3).

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr X Bancourt)
A. Sections of the gallbladder show cholesterol polyp and serosal acute inflammatory infiltrates.

B. Sections of the omentum show focal haemorrhage and focal submesothelial fibroblastic reaction.

Sections of the skin and subcutaneous tissue show fibroblastic reaction with suture granulomas consistent with scar.

Sections of the separate piece of muscle tissue show muscle with adjacent adipose tissue with fibroblastic reaction, chronic inflammation and suture granulomas consistent with previous surgery effect.

Sections of the fallopian tubes are unremarkable. Both ovaries, especially the second ovary shows prominent extracellular mucous on the serosal surface and this is organising. Very focal minimal columnar epithelium is seen. There are also reactive mesothelial cells present. Immunohistochemistry (Block 10 and 12) show positive staining of reactive mesothelial cells for WT-1, calretinin, and CK7. Possible rare nuclei are CXD-2 positive and possible rare cells are CK20 positive.

Sections of the segment of the colon show 11 tubulovillous or tubular adenomas. 12 lymph nodes are identified in the mesentery/mesocolon show reactive changes only.

Comment: There is extracellular mucus on the surface of both ovaries with possible rare CDX2/CK20 positive cells seen on immunohistochemistry. The appearances therefore raise the possibility of Pseudomyxoma peritonei with low grade histologic features.
There are multiple tubular and tubulovillous adenomas of the colon. Clinical correlation is recommended and further investigation could be consdiered.

DIAGNOSIS:
PERITONECTOMY SPECIMEN
- VERY LOW CELLULARITY EXTRACELLULAR MUCUS ON SURFACE OF BOTH OVARIES WITH POSSIBLE RARE CDX-2/CK20 POSITIVE CELLS (POSSIBLE PSEUMOMYXOMA PERITONEI WITH LOW GRADE HISTOLOGIC APPEARANCES).
- COLON WITH MULTIPLE ADENOMATOUS POLYPS
- THERAPY RELATED CHANGES.
