On sectioning, the endometrium is 2 to 4mm in maximum thickness (greatest in the cervical canal) and the myometrium is up to 31mm; containing two fibroids, 6mm and 30mm in maximum diameter.
Blocks:  E1 to E6 - full longitudinal section of anterior body and cervix; E7 to E9 - full longitudinal section of posterior body and cervix; E10 - right cornu; E11 - left cornu; E12 - yellow nodule near peritoneal reflection; E13 - yellow nodule near left cornu (bisected); E14 - anterior serosal nodules (two representative sections).

F.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right ovary&quot;, consists of a 41 x 24 x 13mm pale yellow ovary with a 15 x 7mm puckered region of serosa and three simple cysts, all 5mm in maximum extent, on an otherwise smooth serosal surface.  The attached fallopian tube is 58mm in length x 5mm in diameter and appears unremarkable with the exception of a 7mm parafimbrial cyst.  A 3 x 3mm yellow nodule is noted on the serosal surface of the soft tissue between the ovary and fallopian tube.  The ovary is sectioned transversely into 9 slices and shows a relatively well circumscribed 19 x 11 x approximately 20mm pale yellow lesion underlying the puckered serosal region (slices 4 to 8).  The fallopian tube is sectioned transversely into 11 slices and the fimbrial end bisected longitudinally.
Blocks:  F1 to F4 - right fallopian tube serially embedded from isthmus to fimbria; F5 - ovary, slice three with cyst; F6 &amp; F7 - ovary with yellow lesion and serosal puckering (F7 also with separate serosal nodule), slices 5 and 6. F8-F11 additional blocks ovary.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of 265 x 60 x 10mm of omental fat. Numerous (&gt;15) firm nodules, 2 to 7mm in extent, are scattered throughout the omentum.  Some have a spiculated pale cream cut surface (?fibrosis or tumour).
Blocks:  G1 - two nodules; G2 - five nodules; G3 - one nodule, bisected; G4 - three nodules; G5 - three nodules; G6 &amp; G7 - one nodule bisected per block.

H.  Specimen labelled &quot;Peritoneal nodule&quot;, consists of four irregular fibrofatty tissues, 7 to 20mm in extent and 25 x 15 x 7mm in aggregate.  The two largest pieces are surfaced by presumed pale grey serosa. The largest is trisected and shows an 8 x 2mm firm cream to yellow region extending from the peritoneal surface.  The second piece of presumed serosa also shows an 8 x 2mm thickened area (bisected).
Blocks:  H1 - larger piece bisected; H2 - smaller three pieces (one bisected). AE.

I.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right sidewall&quot;, consists of an 11 x 7 x 3mm irregular grey tissue. Bisected, AE 1 block.

J. Specimen labelled &quot;Nodule bladder peritoneum&quot;, consists of an 8 x 6 x 4mm fibrofatty tissue, surfaced on one side by a possible pale grey serosa.  Bisected, AE 1 block.  (TO: KM; KM/eh 22/4/2067)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr M Bready):
A.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show core biopsies of pancreatic tissue.  There is marked acinar atrophy with replacement dense hyaline type fibrosis. There is background retention of a lobular architecture however interspersed amongst the dense fibrous tissue are occasional atypical tubular glands. The glands show  mild to focally moderate nuclear pleomorphism which is difficult to assess in a frozen section sample.  Features often associated with carcinoma in core biopsy samples such as nuclear size variation of 3:1, conspicuous macronucleoli, disrupted glands, perineural invasion, necrosis in lumina are not definitively present, however the glands are atypical and the context of the appearances seen in specimen B likely represent well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

B.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show a wedge of pancreatic tissue which is partially infiltrated by a well differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows an infiltrative pattern amongst background pancreatic parenchyma which shows variable acinar atrophy.  The glands are tubular with focal secondary lumina and are lined by cells with minimal or mild nuclear pleomorphism and a small to moderate amount eosinophilic cytoplasm.  No morphological evidence of intestinal differentiation such as goblet cells or Paneth cells are seen.  There is associated fibromyxoid desmoplastic stroma and foci of perineural and intraneural invasion are also seen.  No associated extracellular mucin is present.  The sample includes uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma and the ducts here do not show evidence of high grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).  No lymph nodes are identified.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

C.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show oedematous fibrovascular cores surfaced by variably ciliated Mullerian type epithelium showing hierarchical branching.  Although some of the papillae appear unsupported they are not four times as high as they are wide.  Nuclear atypia is mild to moderate.  No features of microinvasion are seen. The features are those of a low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Sections of ovary show invasive adenocarcinoma.  Differentiation varies with predominantly well to moderate differentiation and a minor poorly differentiated component.  The tumour is composed of tubular and cribriform glandular structures within a moderately cellular oedematous desmoplastic stroma.  In addition to small tubular and cribriform structures the tumour also contains a component of more cystically dilated glands a proportion of which are lined by very bland or mildly atypical simple or stratified columnar mucinous epithelium. Expansile nodular or intracystic papillary growth is not seen.  Some of the cystically dilated areas show higher grade nuclear atypia. Whilst the tumour mainly shows destructive stromal invasion with associated desmoplasia, some area including the cysts are associated with ovarian stroma in a pattern resembling an ovarian mucinous borderline neoplasm  with and without intracystic carcinoma .  The poorly differentiated component comprises minor foci (less than 5%) in which there is either single cell infiltration or signet ring-like differentiation (eg D8, D16, D18).  No associated extracellular mucin deposition to indicate pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  No microscopic surface mucin, or surface deposits are seen. Two small areas of surface disruption are noted.    Occasional glands contain necrotic luminal debris which are predominantly of inflammatory cells with some associated necrotic epithelial cells. Invasive adenocarcinoma involves the fallopian tube with invasion of the wall from the serosal surface (D18, D20) reaching the mucosa at the fimbrial end (D21) .  There is focal endometriosis close to the fallopian tube (D21). The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and no serous tubular carcinoma in-situ is seen.  No benign Brenner component is seen. The ovarian hilum is not identified.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.


E.  Sections of uterus show metastatic adenocarcinoma seenpredominantly surface deposits on the anterior surface (E4).  Adenocarcinoma is also present in the vicinity of the right cornua (E10) and close to the posterior peritoneal reflection (E12).  The carcinoma shows similar morphology to the pancreatic and ovarian disease.   There are also foci of endosalpingiosis (eg E5, E7) as well as endometriosis (E13).  The uterus shows a couple of fibroids (E14, E1) and is otherwise unremarkable. The endometrium is predominantly basal but appears inactive.  The ectocervix and and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.

F.  The right ovary is extensively sampled and the attached fallopian tube including fimbrial end entirely embedded and examined.  Sections of ovary confirm a surface serous low grade borderline tumour associated with psammomatous calcifications as well as multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows similar features to that seen in the left ovary and pancreas.  The deposits are seen on the surface of the ovary and also as a single expansile nodule. The expansile nodule shows areas in which the malignant glands are present with  ovarian stroma as well as areas with stromal  desmoplasia. The surface deposits which show similar cytomorphology are present amongst desmoplastic stroma.  The glands show a tubular and cribriform morphology with some poorly differentiated areas with single cell growth (eg F6).  No pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  Metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is also seen within the right ovarian hilum (F11).  Definite lymphovascular invasion is not identified.  Foci of endometriosis are also seen (F11).The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and is unremarkable and uninvolved.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the adenocarcinoma stains as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

In contrast to the adenocarcinoma the serous borderline tumour shows typical expression for PAX8, WT1, CK7, ER and PR. CK19 is also positive while CK20 and CDX2 are negative.

G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar morphology to that seen within the ovaries and pancreas. The carcinoma is composed of small tubular and cribriform glands within a desmoplastic stroma and is seen on the serosal surface associated with mesothelial cell reaction.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are seen both in the vicinity of tumour and separately.  Foci of endosalpingiosis are also seen (G5 and G6). One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stroma. The carcinoma appears well to moderately differentiated with well formed tubular or cribriform glands.  One small lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

I &amp; J.  Sections of fibroadipose tissue show a deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar features to that seen in the other sites.  The carcinoma is well to moderately differentiated.


COMMENT:
The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr M Penrod who favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Miquel comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Pancreatic core biopsy (frozen section):
-    Atypical mucinous epithelium which in this context is consistent with adenocarcinoma.

B.  Pancreatic biopsy (frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion (see comment).

C.  Right ovarian lesion (frozen section):
-    Low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Left ovary and fallopian tube (including frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma within ovary and fallopian tube (see comment).

E.  Uterus:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis and endometriosis.
-    Fibroids.

F.  Right ovary and fallopian tube:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma in ovary.
-    Ovarian low grade serous borderline tumour.
-    Uninvolved fallopian tube

G.  Omentum:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis.

H.  Peritoneal nodule:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

I.   Right side wall:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

J.   Nodule peritoneum:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The findings were discussed with Drs M Maddy &amp; M Saye and  Profs. M Strohm and M Lownsbery.

Comments:

It appears to be located mostly in the submucosa and undermines the mucosa, with occasional tongues extending up and rupturing through the mucosal surface.  There is extensive serosal involvement.  The immunostaining pattern is unusual and may represent the effect of chemotherapy. The loss of CDX2 and CK20 and gain of CK7 in colorectal carcinoma has been described in the literature and is associated with poor prognosis (Loss of CDX2 expression is associated with poor prognosis in colorectal cancer patients. Bae JM et al. World J Gastroenterol 2015 February 7; 21(5): 1457-1467). I am not entirely able to exclude a metastasis on morphology and immunohistochemistry, as similar features can be seen in adenocarcinomas of the upper gastrointestinal tract. MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr V Yohe):
A.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show core biopsies of pancreatic tissue.  There is marked acinar atrophy with replacement dense hyaline type fibrosis. There is background retention of a lobular architecture however interspersed amongst the dense fibrous tissue are occasional atypical tubular glands. The glands show  mild to focally moderate nuclear pleomorphism which is difficult to assess in a frozen section sample.  Features often associated with carcinoma in core biopsy samples such as nuclear size variation of 3:1, conspicuous macronucleoli, disrupted glands, perineural invasion, necrosis in lumina are not definitively present, however the glands are atypical and the context of the appearances seen in specimen B likely represent well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

B.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show a wedge of pancreatic tissue which is partially infiltrated by a well differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows an infiltrative pattern amongst background pancreatic parenchyma which shows variable acinar atrophy.  The glands are tubular with focal secondary lumina and are lined by cells with minimal or mild nuclear pleomorphism and a small to moderate amount eosinophilic cytoplasm.  No morphological evidence of intestinal differentiation such as goblet cells or Paneth cells are seen.  There is associated fibromyxoid desmoplastic stroma and foci of perineural and intraneural invasion are also seen.  No associated extracellular mucin is present.  The sample includes uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma and the ducts here do not show evidence of high grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).  No lymph nodes are identified.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

C.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show oedematous fibrovascular cores surfaced by variably ciliated Mullerian type epithelium showing hierarchical branching.  Although some of the papillae appear unsupported they are not four times as high as they are wide.  Nuclear atypia is mild to moderate.  No features of microinvasion are seen. The features are those of a low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Sections of ovary show invasive adenocarcinoma.  Differentiation varies with predominantly well to moderate differentiation and a minor poorly differentiated component.  The tumour is composed of tubular and cribriform glandular structures within a moderately cellular oedematous desmoplastic stroma.  In addition to small tubular and cribriform structures the tumour also contains a component of more cystically dilated glands a proportion of which are lined by very bland or mildly atypical simple or stratified columnar mucinous epithelium. Expansile nodular or intracystic papillary growth is not seen.  Some of the cystically dilated areas show higher grade nuclear atypia. Whilst the tumour mainly shows destructive stromal invasion with associated desmoplasia, some area including the cysts are associated with ovarian stroma in a pattern resembling an ovarian mucinous borderline neoplasm  with and without intracystic carcinoma .  The poorly differentiated component comprises minor foci (less than 5%) in which there is either single cell infiltration or signet ring-like differentiation (eg D8, D16, D18).  No associated extracellular mucin deposition to indicate pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  No microscopic surface mucin, or surface deposits are seen. Two small areas of surface disruption are noted.    Occasional glands contain necrotic luminal debris which are predominantly of inflammatory cells with some associated necrotic epithelial cells. Invasive adenocarcinoma involves the fallopian tube with invasion of the wall from the serosal surface (D18, D20) reaching the mucosa at the fimbrial end (D21) .  There is focal endometriosis close to the fallopian tube (D21). The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and no serous tubular carcinoma in-situ is seen.  No benign Brenner component is seen. The ovarian hilum is not identified.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.


E.  Sections of uterus show metastatic adenocarcinoma seenpredominantly surface deposits on the anterior surface (E4).  Adenocarcinoma is also present in the vicinity of the right cornua (E10) and close to the posterior peritoneal reflection (E12).  The carcinoma shows similar morphology to the pancreatic and ovarian disease.   There are also foci of endosalpingiosis (eg E5, E7) as well as endometriosis (E13).  The uterus shows a couple of fibroids (E14, E1) and is otherwise unremarkable. The endometrium is predominantly basal but appears inactive.  The ectocervix and and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.

F.  The right ovary is extensively sampled and the attached fallopian tube including fimbrial end entirely embedded and examined.  Sections of ovary confirm a surface serous low grade borderline tumour associated with psammomatous calcifications as well as multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows similar features to that seen in the left ovary and pancreas.  The deposits are seen on the surface of the ovary and also as a single expansile nodule. The expansile nodule shows areas in which the malignant glands are present with  ovarian stroma as well as areas with stromal  desmoplasia. The surface deposits which show similar cytomorphology are present amongst desmoplastic stroma.  The glands show a tubular and cribriform morphology with some poorly differentiated areas with single cell growth (eg F6).  No pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  Metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is also seen within the right ovarian hilum (F11).  Definite lymphovascular invasion is not identified.  Foci of endometriosis are also seen (F11).The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and is unremarkable and uninvolved.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the adenocarcinoma stains as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

In contrast to the adenocarcinoma the serous borderline tumour shows typical expression for PAX8, WT1, CK7, ER and PR. CK19 is also positive while CK20 and CDX2 are negative.

G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar morphology to that seen within the ovaries and pancreas. The carcinoma is composed of small tubular and cribriform glands within a desmoplastic stroma and is seen on the serosal surface associated with mesothelial cell reaction.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are seen both in the vicinity of tumour and separately.  Foci of endosalpingiosis are also seen (G5 and G6). One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stroma. The carcinoma appears well to moderately differentiated with well formed tubular or cribriform glands.  One small lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

I &amp; J.  Sections of fibroadipose tissue show a deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar features to that seen in the other sites.  The carcinoma is well to moderately differentiated.


COMMENT:
The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr V Bognar who favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Lucius comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Pancreatic core biopsy (frozen section):
-    Atypical mucinous epithelium which in this context is consistent with adenocarcinoma.

B.  Pancreatic biopsy (frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion (see comment).

C.  Right ovarian lesion (frozen section):
-    Low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Left ovary and fallopian tube (including frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma within ovary and fallopian tube (see comment).

E.  Uterus:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis and endometriosis.
-    Fibroids.

F.  Right ovary and fallopian tube:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma in ovary.
-    Ovarian low grade serous borderline tumour.
-    Uninvolved fallopian tube

G.  Omentum:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis.

H.  Peritoneal nodule:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

I.   Right side wall:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

J.   Nodule peritoneum:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The findings were discussed with Drs V Basques &amp; V Cull and  Profs. V Gollogly and V Segee.

MICROSCOPICinsrsid2696183 :  (Dr K Paszek)
Sections show extensive involvement of the specimen by low grade mucinous neoplasm.
The appendiceal mucosa is replaced by mucinous neoplasm with villiform/papillary architecture and low nuc lear grade. Focally, the mucinous neoplasm extends through the thickness of the muscularis propria, virtually to the level of periappendiceal fat. However, there is no full appendiceal wall thickness perforation in the sections examined.
There is extensive intra-abdominal low grade mucinous neoplasm. There are deposits of tumour involving the mesentery of the large bowel, the serosal surface of the large bowel, small bowel, stomach, gallbladder, spleen and li ver. There is extensive involvement of omental fat. The deposits are characterised by extensive extracellular mucin and of moderate cellularity characterised by strips of mucinous epithelium with low to intermediate nuclear grade. No high  grade epithelial changes are seen, and no frankly infiltrative architecture is seen.
Representative sections of the distal (unstapled) margin of the partial gastrectomy show a 10mm neuroendocrine tumour. The tumour infiltra tes from the base of the mucosa, through partial but not full thickness muscularis propria. Tumour is characterised by trabecular and gyriformform architecture and is mitotically inactive. Immunostains including Ki-67 are pending and a fu rther report will follow. The neuroendocrine tumour virtually forms the inked resection margin with only a very thin rim (less than 0.1mm of intervening fibrovascular tissue in the section examined).
Sections of the small and  large bowel mucosa are unremarkable. Sections of the stomach show chronic gastritis with patchy intestinal metaplasia. The splenic parenchyma is unremarkabl .

- INCIDENTAL 9mm GASTRIC NEUROENDOCRINE TUMOUR EXTENDING INTO BUT NOT THROUGH MUSCULARIS PROPRIA. Ki-67 AND GRADE TO FOLLOW.

The partial gastrecto my component of the specimen has been further sampled.
There is generalised moderate chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia and mild atrophy in the body. Helicobacter are not seen.
Immunostains confirm a 9mm neuroe ndocrine tumour. There is positive tumour staining for chromogrannin, synaptophysin, CD56 and CAM5.2 with perinuclear dot staining. There is focal staining for S100. Positive gastrin staining in the adjacent mucosa confirms location in th e antrum. The proliferative index on Ki67 is 2% (800 cells counted). Review of the tumour shows a mitotic rate of 1/10hpf and focal lymphvascular space invasion is seen.
The features are those of a  grade 1 (WHO 2010) neuroendocrine tumour.

Specimen labelled &quot;Right ovary&quot;, consists of a 41 x 24 x 13mm pale yellow ovary with a 15 x 7mm puckered region of serosa and three simple cysts, all 5mm in maximum extent, on an otherwise smooth serosal surface.  The attached fallopian tube is 58mm in length x 5mm in diameter and appears unremarkable with the exception of a 7mm parafimbrial cyst.  A 3 x 3mm yellow nodule is noted on the serosal surface of the soft tissue between the ovary and fallopian tube.  The ovary is sectioned transversely into 9 slices and shows a relatively well circumscribed 19 x 11 x approximately 20mm pale yellow lesion underlying the puckered serosal region (slices 4 to 8).  The fallopian tube is sectioned transversely into 11 slices and the fimbrial end bisected longitudinally.
Blocks:  F1 to F4 - right fallopian tube serially embedded from isthmus to fimbria; F5 - ovary, slice three with cyst; F6 &amp; F7 - ovary with yellow lesion and serosal puckering (F7 also with separate serosal nodule), slices 5 and 6. F8-F11 additional blocks ovary.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of 265 x 60 x 10mm of omental fat. Numerous (&gt;15) firm nodules, 2 to 7mm in extent, are scattered throughout the omentum.  Some have a spiculated pale cream cut surface (?fibrosis or tumour).
Blocks:  G1 - two nodules; G2 - five nodules; G3 - one nodule, bisected; G4 - three nodules; G5 - three nodules; G6 &amp; G7 - one nodule bisected per block.

H.  Specimen labelled &quot;Peritoneal nodule&quot;, consists of four irregular fibrofatty tissues, 7 to 20mm in extent and 25 x 15 x 7mm in aggregate.  The two largest pieces are surfaced by presumed pale grey serosa. The largest is trisected and shows an 8 x 2mm firm cream to yellow region extending from the peritoneal surface.  The second piece of presumed serosa also shows an 8 x 2mm thickened area (bisected).
Blocks:  H1 - larger piece bisected; H2 - smaller three pieces (one bisected). AE.

I.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right sidewall&quot;, consists of an 11 x 7 x 3mm irregular grey tissue. Bisected, AE 1 block.

J. Specimen labelled &quot;Nodule bladder peritoneum&quot;, consists of an 8 x 6 x 4mm fibrofatty tissue, surfaced on one side by a possible pale grey serosa.  Bisected, AE 1 block.  (TO: KM; KM/eh 22/4/2067)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr W Baitner):
A.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show core biopsies of pancreatic tissue.  There is marked acinar atrophy with replacement dense hyaline type fibrosis. There is background retention of a lobular architecture however interspersed amongst the dense fibrous tissue are occasional atypical tubular glands. The glands show  mild to focally moderate nuclear pleomorphism which is difficult to assess in a frozen section sample.  Features often associated with carcinoma in core biopsy samples such as nuclear size variation of 3:1, conspicuous macronucleoli, disrupted glands, perineural invasion, necrosis in lumina are not definitively present, however the glands are atypical and the context of the appearances seen in specimen B likely represent well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

B.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show a wedge of pancreatic tissue which is partially infiltrated by a well differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows an infiltrative pattern amongst background pancreatic parenchyma which shows variable acinar atrophy.  The glands are tubular with focal secondary lumina and are lined by cells with minimal or mild nuclear pleomorphism and a small to moderate amount eosinophilic cytoplasm.  No morphological evidence of intestinal differentiation such as goblet cells or Paneth cells are seen.  There is associated fibromyxoid desmoplastic stroma and foci of perineural and intraneural invasion are also seen.  No associated extracellular mucin is present.  The sample includes uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma and the ducts here do not show evidence of high grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).  No lymph nodes are identified.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

C.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show oedematous fibrovascular cores surfaced by variably ciliated Mullerian type epithelium showing hierarchical branching.  Although some of the papillae appear unsupported they are not four times as high as they are wide.  Nuclear atypia is mild to moderate.  No features of microinvasion are seen. The features are those of a low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Sections of ovary show invasive adenocarcinoma.  Differentiation varies with predominantly well to moderate differentiation and a minor poorly differentiated component.  The tumour is composed of tubular and cribriform glandular structures within a moderately cellular oedematous desmoplastic stroma.  In addition to small tubular and cribriform structures the tumour also contains a component of more cystically dilated glands a proportion of which are lined by very bland or mildly atypical simple or stratified columnar mucinous epithelium. Expansile nodular or intracystic papillary growth is not seen.  Some of the cystically dilated areas show higher grade nuclear atypia. Whilst the tumour mainly shows destructive stromal invasion with associated desmoplasia, some area including the cysts are associated with ovarian stroma in a pattern resembling an ovarian mucinous borderline neoplasm  with and without intracystic carcinoma .  The poorly differentiated component comprises minor foci (less than 5%) in which there is either single cell infiltration or signet ring-like differentiation (eg D8, D16, D18).  No associated extracellular mucin deposition to indicate pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  No microscopic surface mucin, or surface deposits are seen. Two small areas of surface disruption are noted.    Occasional glands contain necrotic luminal debris which are predominantly of inflammatory cells with some associated necrotic epithelial cells. Invasive adenocarcinoma involves the fallopian tube with invasion of the wall from the serosal surface (D18, D20) reaching the mucosa at the fimbrial end (D21) .  There is focal endometriosis close to the fallopian tube (D21). The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and no serous tubular carcinoma in-situ is seen.  No benign Brenner component is seen. The ovarian hilum is not identified.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.


E.  Sections of uterus show metastatic adenocarcinoma seenpredominantly surface deposits on the anterior surface (E4).  Adenocarcinoma is also present in the vicinity of the right cornua (E10) and close to the posterior peritoneal reflection (E12).  The carcinoma shows similar morphology to the pancreatic and ovarian disease.   There are also foci of endosalpingiosis (eg E5, E7) as well as endometriosis (E13).  The uterus shows a couple of fibroids (E14, E1) and is otherwise unremarkable. The endometrium is predominantly basal but appears inactive.  The ectocervix and and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.

F.  The right ovary is extensively sampled and the attached fallopian tube including fimbrial end entirely embedded and examined.  Sections of ovary confirm a surface serous low grade borderline tumour associated with psammomatous calcifications as well as multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows similar features to that seen in the left ovary and pancreas.  The deposits are seen on the surface of the ovary and also as a single expansile nodule. The expansile nodule shows areas in which the malignant glands are present with  ovarian stroma as well as areas with stromal  desmoplasia. The surface deposits which show similar cytomorphology are present amongst desmoplastic stroma.  The glands show a tubular and cribriform morphology with some poorly differentiated areas with single cell growth (eg F6).  No pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  Metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is also seen within the right ovarian hilum (F11).  Definite lymphovascular invasion is not identified.  Foci of endometriosis are also seen (F11).The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and is unremarkable and uninvolved.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the adenocarcinoma stains as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

In contrast to the adenocarcinoma the serous borderline tumour shows typical expression for PAX8, WT1, CK7, ER and PR. CK19 is also positive while CK20 and CDX2 are negative.

G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar morphology to that seen within the ovaries and pancreas. The carcinoma is composed of small tubular and cribriform glands within a desmoplastic stroma and is seen on the serosal surface associated with mesothelial cell reaction.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are seen both in the vicinity of tumour and separately.  Foci of endosalpingiosis are also seen (G5 and G6). One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stroma. The carcinoma appears well to moderately differentiated with well formed tubular or cribriform glands.  One small lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

I &amp; J.  Sections of fibroadipose tissue show a deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar features to that seen in the other sites.  The carcinoma is well to moderately differentiated.


COMMENT:
The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr W Schied who favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Shannon comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Pancreatic core biopsy (frozen section):
-    Atypical mucinous epithelium which in this context is consistent with adenocarcinoma.

B.  Pancreatic biopsy (frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion (see comment).

C.  Right ovarian lesion (frozen section):
-    Low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Left ovary and fallopian tube (including frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma within ovary and fallopian tube (see comment).

E.  Uterus:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis and endometriosis.
-    Fibroids.

F.  Right ovary and fallopian tube:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma in ovary.
-    Ovarian low grade serous borderline tumour.
-    Uninvolved fallopian tube

G.  Omentum:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis.

H.  Peritoneal nodule:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

I.   Right side wall:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

J.   Nodule peritoneum:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The findings were discussed with Drs W Hect &amp; W Mcnatt and  Profs. W Arnspiger and W Ezdebski.

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr S Bumby)
Sections show extensive moderately differentiated metastatic adenocarcinoma. There is involvement of the scar tissue at the site of the previous right hemicolectomy anastomosis. There is extensive involvement of the omental tissue, together with involvement of the two further segments of large bowel. The foci within the bowel segments involve all layers of the bowel wall from the mucosa through to the serosa including the peritoneal surface.

The adenocarcinoma is characterised by variable differentiation ranging from larger cystic structures lined by relatively low-grade epithelium,  to moderately differentiated cellular aggregates and trabeculae without gland formation. Immunostains show that the carcinoma is positive for CK7 with probable focal weak positivity for CDX-2. The stains for CK20, ER, p16, TTF1 and PAX-8 are negative.

Comment: The appearances are those of widespread metastatic adenocarcinoma. The appearances and immunoprofile are unusual for an appendix primary.

REDO RIGHT HEMICOLECTOMY, SIGMOID COLON RESECTION, OMENTUM

CLINICAL:
?Ovarian malignancy. General clinical history: bilateral ovarian masses, abnormal appendix, raised Ca 125, ascites.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left tube and ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and attached multicystic mass, 100 x 85 x 60mm. The fallopian tube measures 65mm in length and 7mm in maximum diameter. No normal ovary is identified. The fallopian tube is attached to the mass. The mass is multicystic and has a mostly smooth outer surface with some small nodular deposits. The cut surface shows a solid cystic architecture. Two thirds of the mass is occupied by the solid component. No obvious areas of necrosis or haemorrhage are seen. There is a unilocular cyst with clear serous fluid and wall thickness of less than 1mm. There is also a pale yellow friable mass, 40 x 20 x 40mm, inside the cyst. Blocks: 1 to 10 - RS solid cystic mass; 11 to 15 - fallopian tube and fimbria; 16 - for Biobanking. RS. Shown to Dr E Mervyn.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right tube and ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and a solid cystic mass, 90 x 55 x 45mm. The fallopian tube measures 70mm in length and up to 8mm in maximum diameter. No normal ovary identified. The solid cystic mass has a mostly smooth outer surface with some small pale nodular deposits. On section, the mass appears to be 90% occupied by solid areas. The solid areas appear multilobulated and pale. No obvious haemorrhage or necrosis is seen. There is a unilocular cyst with thin serous fluid. The cyst wall is less than 1mm thick. Blocks: 1 to 10 - representative solid cystic mass; 11 to 13 - fallopian tube and fimbria. RS

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Uterus and cervix&quot;, consists of a uterus with attached cervix weighing 56g in total. The uterus measures 55 x 40 x 25mm and has a smooth and shiny serosal surface. The ectocervix measures 30 x 25mm and has an unremarkable surface. On section, the endometrium is less than 1mm thick and the myometrium is 12mm in maximum thickness. The myometrium contains two fibroids ranging from 5 to 8mm in maximum diameter. The lower cervix appears multicystic. No fallopian tube or ovary is attached. Blocks: 1 to 3 - full LS anterior body and cervix; 4 - part of anterior uterus with fibroid; 5 to 7 - full LS posterior body and cervix. RS

D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Appendix&quot;, consists of an appendix, 60mm in length and up to 8mm in maximum diameter, with attached mesoappendix up to 25mm in width. The resection margin is inked. The serosal surface is dull and haemorrhagic. There appear to be nodules attached to the tip of the appendix, 8 to 18mm in maximum diameter. The cut surface of the nodules are pale and firm. The appendix wall is 1mm thick and contains cream to brown material in the lumen. Blocks: 1 - LS base of appendix; 2 &amp; 3 - mid TS; 4 &amp; 5 - LS tip of appendix and attached nodules; 6 - mesoappendix. AE

E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Pouch of Douglas&quot;, consists of a tan and fatty fragment of tissue, 23 x 15 x 7mm. Resection margin inked. TAE 2 blocks.

F.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal nodule&quot;, consists of a fatty and fibrous nodule, 12 x 10 x 8mm and detached tan fatty tissue fragments, 15 x 12 x 5mm in aggregate. Nodule inked. Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - rectal nodule; 3 - fragments. AE.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of an elongated piece of fatty tissue, 330 x 130 x 5mm. There are multiple (about 5) nodules in the omentum, ranging from 7 to 70mm in maximum diameter. The largest nodule appears multinodular and pale with a pale and firm cut surface. RS of the nodule embedded into five blocks. RS. Shown to Dr E Demelis.   (TO:DN/ta 27/5/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr E Loethen):
A. The sections show high grade serous carcinoma.  Sheets of tumour, tubular and papillary structures are seen. In some areas, marked cellular pleomorphism is present (e.g., slide A2). Mitoses are found including abnormal mitotic figures (e.g., slide A6). Tumour cells are found within dilated thin walled lymphovascular channels within the tumour (slide A3). The tumour extends to the surface of the mass focally (e.g., slides A7, A10).
There are nodules of high grade serous carcinoma in the soft tissues adjacent to the fallopian tube (slides A12-A14). There are areas of tubal carcinoma in situ and invasive carcinoma in the fimbria (slide A15).  Tumour cells are found within thin walled lymphovascular channels (e.g., slide A12). Tumour cells are found within the lumen of the fallopian tube (slide A11).

Immunohistochemistry shows diffuse, strong nuclear expression of PAX 8, WT1 and P53 antigens in the tumour cells.  There is weak to moderate expression of oestrogen receptor antigen in most of the tumour cells.  Progesterone receptor antigen is moderately to strongly expressed in about 5% of the tumour cells.  Her 2 antigen is not expressed.

B. The sections show a mass formed by high grade serous carcinoma, which reaches the surface of the mass (slides B9, B10).   The tumour cells are pleomorphic and some show elongated nuclei (slide B4) but there is no obvious sarcomatoid component.  Numerous mitoses are found in some areas (&gt; 20 / hpf), including atypical forms (slide B4). Tumour cells are found within dilated, thin walled lymphovascular channels (slides B4, B10).
Tumour cells are found within the lumen of the fallopian tube (slide B12).

C. High grade serous carcinoma is seen in the serosa and soft tissues around the posterior uterine body (slide C6) and cervix (slide C7).  The tumour nodules are seen on the soft tissue margins and abut the myometrium. Tumour cells are found within thin walled lymphovascular channels (slide C6).    The endometrium is thin and inactive. Scattered intramural leiomyomata are seen, showing no atypical features.  The cervix shows Nabothian cysts and patchy moderate chronic inflammation.

D. The appendix shows a hyperplastic polyp. Tumour nodules are seen in the mesoappendix and serosa (slides D2, D4-D6), invading into the muscularis propria (slide D4).

E. The sections show fatty tissue with nodules of high grade serous carcinoma in a desmoplastic stroma.

F. The sections show nodules of high grade serous carcinoma with areas of marked atypia (slides F1, F2), invading in a desmoplastic stroma.

G. Large areas of high grade serous tumour are seen in the omentum. Scattered sheets of poorly differentiated carcinoma are seen, with many mitoses including atypical forms (slide G3). There is no obvious sarcomatoid differentiation.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left ovary and fallopian tube: High grade serous carcinoma, tubal carcinoma in situ, lymphovascular invasion present.
B. Right ovary and fallopian tube: High grade serous carcinoma, lymphovascular invasion present.
C. Uterus: High grade serous carcinoma in serosa.
D. Appendix: High grade serous carcinoma in serosa and mesoappendix.
E-G. Pouch of Douglas, rectal nodule and omentum: High grade serous carcinoma.

Positive staining of a carcinoma for MLH1,  PMS2,  MSH2  and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The antibodies used are not fully characterised for routine diagnostic use. Results may be affected by storage and fixation of specimens, and should be interpreted in conjunction with other investigation, including MSI testing where possible.

Sections of the separate fragments of tissue consist of predominantly necrotic tumour including some fragments with a focal phyllodes-like growth pattern. There is a predominant stromal component (sarcomatous overgrowth). Some glands with columnar epithelium and with squamous metaplasia are identified. The stroma shows cytologic pleomorphism and increased cellularity with some subepithelial condensation. Multinucleated tumour giant cells are seen. Mitotic activity is present (up to 23 mitoses per 10 hpf).


B. The sections show mesothelium with reactive changes and with macrophage and chronic inflammatory reaction of the stroma including and with acute inflammatory reaction.

C. The sections show omentum with reactive surface epithelial change, mesothelial changes and macrophage reaction on the serosal surface

Comment: The appearances of the uterine tumour and separate fragments of tumour are those of adenosarcoma with sarcomatous overgrowth. It appears confined to the endometrium (stage 1A). There are also benign serous cystadenofibromas/serous inclusions  and endometriosis/serosal adhesions of the ovaries, and endometriosis/serosal adhesions of the posterior uterine serosa/pouch of douglas. Clinical correlation is recommended.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. UTERUS
- ADENOSARCOMA WITH SARCOMATOUS OVERGROWTH (STAGE 1A).

B. LARGE BOWEL SEROSA
- REACTIVE CHANGES/ADEHSIONS AND MIXED ACUTE AND CHRONIC INFLAMMATION.

C. OMENTUM
- NEGATIVE FOR MALIGNANCY.

&quot;GALLBLADDER, SPLEEN, RIGHT COLON, SMALL BOWEL, PERITONEAL DISEASE&quot;.

Peritoneal Disease - Multiple strips of diaphragm and peritoneal tissue measuring in aggregate 150x150x100mm.  There is diffuse tumour involvement of all pieces.
(7-9 representative tissue)
Segments of Bowel - Three segments of bowel measuring up to 150, 140 and 400mm in length.  Each piece has dense tumour deposits over the serosal surface and mesentery.  One piece appears to have some fibrinous exudate present also.  On opening the mucosa is oedematousin areas but otherwise unremarkable.
(10&amp;11 LS resection margins piece one; 12 serosal tumour deposit piece 1; 13&amp;14 LS resection margins piece two; 15-18 serosal and mesenteric tumour deposits piece two; 19&amp;20 LS resection margin piece three; 21&amp;22 serosal tumour deposits piece three)
Right Colon - A segment of bowel loop measuring in aggregate 140x100x70mm.  It is predominantly small bowel with ileocaecal valve and caecum attached at resectionmargin.  There is an area of scarring in the caecum and there is a thickened appendix present adherent to the bowel loop measuring up to 50mm in length and 12mm in external diameter.  It has a pale firm appearance.  The serosal and mesenteric surfaces are carpet by gelatinous tumour deposit.
(23 LS resection margin; 24 representative serosal deposits; 25&amp;26 LS distal appendix with mesenteric nodes; 27 TS mid appendix; 28 LS proximal appendix; 29&amp;30 representative mesenteric nodes; 31&amp;32 tumour reserve block).  RS (M-32/ED/ank)
MICROSCOPIC:  (Z Bassett)
The sections of the gallbladder show deposits of extracellular mucus on the serosal surface with some groups and strips of attenuated cuboidal epithelium with low grade nuclear cytology.
Sections of the spleen show normal appearing splenic parenchyma.  On the serosal surface, there are deposits of extracellular mucus associated with columnar mucinous epithelium with intermediate gradecytology.  There is also infiltration of reactive fibroblastic connective tissue by small groups of cells and infiltrative pattern glands showing intermediate grade cytology including nuclear hyperchromasia and  nuclear shape and membraneirregularities.
Sections of the omentum and peritoneal tissue show deposits of extracellular mucus associated with dense fibrous connective tissue and with columnar mucinous epithelium with intermediate nuclear grade features.  There is infiltration of connective tissue with reactive desmoplastic stroma by variably sized glands and small nests of tumour cells.   A focus of endometriosis is also identified.
Sections of the three separate segments of bowel show small and large bowel with normal mucosa and normal wall.  The serosa and adventitia contains mucinous tumour with similar appearances to that seen in the previous specimen including intermediate grade nuclear cytology.Several mesenteric lymph nodes are seen and show reactive changes only.
Sections of the right hemicolectomy specimen show an appendix in which the distal appendix is occupied by a tumour with combined morphology. There is a component of villous pattern mucinous tumour that penetrates the wall of the appendix to reach the adjacent periappendiceal connective tissues with intermediate nucleargrade features and desmoplastic stromal reaction and with associated metaplastic calcification. There is an associated usual type carcinoid (neuroendocrine tumour grade 1) growing in nests and cords and small groups of cells, and forming rosette structures.  The carcinoid shows granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli.  The carcinoid tumour component measures 20mm in diameter and infiltrates through the full thickness of the wall of the appendix to focally involve the mesoappendix.
Fourteen periappendiceal and mesenteric lymph nodes are identified and show reactive changes only.  The proximal and distal margins of the hemicolectomy specimen are unremarkable.
Immunohistochemistry (Block 25 &#8211; distal appendix): The mucinous tumour shows strongstaining for CDX2 and CK20, and moderate staining for CK7. The carcinoid tumour shows positive stianing for CAM5.2, CDX-2, synaptophysin, chromogranin, and with less than 2% staining with Ki-67
Comment:  The appearances are those of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma involving the peritoneal surfaces with associated prominent extracellular mucus production (pseudomyxoma peritonei clinical pattern).  In the appendix, there is a combined mucinous tumour consistent with mucinous adenocarcinoma that penetrates through the appendiceal wall, and with associated with ususal type carcinoid (neuroendocrine tumour grade 1).  No evidence of metastatic spread of the carcinoid component identified in the sections examined.
DIAGNOSIS:
PERITONECTOMY SPECIMEN:
- MODERATELY DIFFERENTIATED MUCINOUS ADENOCARCINOMA WITH PSEUDOMYXOMA PERITONEI CLINICAL PATTERN; COMBINED MUCINOUS ADENOCARCINOMA AND CARCINOID TUMOUR OF APPENDIX - SEE TEXT FOR DETAILS.

The tumour extends directly into the caecum at the base of the appendix with involvement of caecal wall and submucosa.  Extranodal deposits of well differentiated neuroendocrine tumour are also seen in appendiceal mesentery as well as on the caecal serosa adjacent to the appendiceal base.

The rest of the colon shows an uncomplicated diverticulum and melanosis coli.  The small bowel shows no significant abnormality.

CLINICAL:
Right forearm lesion suture proximal.  Tissue biobanking.  Sarcoma - previous XRT.


MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Right forearm lesion stitch proximal&quot;, consists of a 90 x 87 x 10mm somewhat circular excision of skin with a suture present towards one end as described and will be designated 12 o&apos;clock.  In the centre of the excision is a 50 x 43mm nodule.  Skeletal muscle is present on the deep surface.  3 o&apos;clock inked blue and 9 o&apos;clock inked black.  Specimen is sectioned from proximal to distal into nine slices.  There is a lobulated tan tumour 55 x 45 x 25mm.  The tumour is 22mm from the 3 o&apos;clock margin, 25mm from the 9 o&apos;clock margin and abuts the deep margin.  30% of the tumour is possibly necrotic and there are areas of myxoid change.  Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - LS proximal; 3 &amp; 4 - tumour; 5 &amp; 6 - tumour; 7 - closest 3 o&apos;clock margin; 8 to 12 - full face slice 5 (8 - closest  9 o&apos;clock margin); 13 to 15 - tumour; 16 &amp; 17 - LS (distal); 18 - biobank.  See diagram.  (TO:YL/ec 29/10/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr J Carrales):
Sections show skin excised to include subcutaneous fat plus a small amount of underlying skeletal muscle. There is a lobulated and somewhat circumscribed cellular tumour centred in the subcutaneous fat. The tumour focally bulges into deep dermis. The superficial dermis, epidermis and skeletal muscle are uninvolved. The tumour is composed of compact fascicles of plump spindle cells with moderate amounts of lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei and one to two nucleoli. Mitotic figures are occasionally seen and focally number up to 4 per 10 HPF. Necrosis is not identified. There are moderate numbers of admixed inflammatory cells including lymphocytes, plasma cells and eosinophils within the tumour. The tumour also shows nodular areas of hyalinisation and myxoid change associated with foamy histiocytes and haemosiderin laden macrophages. These alteration is regarded as treatment related changes and is seen in approximately 60% of the tumour. No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is seen.

The tumour cells show the following immunoprofile:
-  Positive:  EMA.
-  Equivocal:  S100 (scattered tumour cells, no more than 5%) and Melan A (faint cytoplasmic staining in around 1% of tumour cells).
-  Negative:  MNF116, Cam5.2, CK5/6, SOX10, HMB45, MUM1, CD34, SMA, desmin, myogenin, STAT6, MUC4 and ALK.
Nuclear expression of H3K37m3 is retained.
The Ki-67 proliferation index is up to around 10% at hotspots by visual estimation.

The overall features are those of a malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.

The cellular tumour mass itself is 1 mm from the deep margin (Block 14). However, the tissue deep to the tumour has a paucicellular and loose myxoid appearance in which there are interspersed atypical cells . These cells may represent reactive atypia in benign stromal cells although tumour cells with treatment effect can show a similar cytology and as such, definite clearance of tumour at the deep margin cannot be guaranteed. This loose myxoid change is present at the deep margin over at least a 5 mm front (Blocks 13, 14 &amp; 15). The tumour mass and deep loose myxoid stromal change are &gt; 10 mm from all peripheral margins.


DIAGNOSIS:
Excision of lesion, right forearm (post radiotherapy):  Malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with treatment effect

J. Specimen labelled &quot;Nodule bladder peritoneum&quot;, consists of an 8 x 6 x 4mm fibrofatty tissue, surfaced on one side by a possible pale grey serosa.  Bisected, AE 1 block.  (TO: KM; KM/eh 22/4/2067)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr W Capitano):
A.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show core biopsies of pancreatic tissue.  There is marked acinar atrophy with replacement dense hyaline type fibrosis. There is background retention of a lobular architecture however interspersed amongst the dense fibrous tissue are occasional atypical tubular glands. The glands show  mild to focally moderate nuclear pleomorphism which is difficult to assess in a frozen section sample.  Features often associated with carcinoma in core biopsy samples such as nuclear size variation of 3:1, conspicuous macronucleoli, disrupted glands, perineural invasion, necrosis in lumina are not definitively present, however the glands are atypical and the context of the appearances seen in specimen B likely represent well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

B.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show a wedge of pancreatic tissue which is partially infiltrated by a well differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows an infiltrative pattern amongst background pancreatic parenchyma which shows variable acinar atrophy.  The glands are tubular with focal secondary lumina and are lined by cells with minimal or mild nuclear pleomorphism and a small to moderate amount eosinophilic cytoplasm.  No morphological evidence of intestinal differentiation such as goblet cells or Paneth cells are seen.  There is associated fibromyxoid desmoplastic stroma and foci of perineural and intraneural invasion are also seen.  No associated extracellular mucin is present.  The sample includes uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma and the ducts here do not show evidence of high grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).  No lymph nodes are identified.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

C.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show oedematous fibrovascular cores surfaced by variably ciliated Mullerian type epithelium showing hierarchical branching.  Although some of the papillae appear unsupported they are not four times as high as they are wide.  Nuclear atypia is mild to moderate.  No features of microinvasion are seen. The features are those of a low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Sections of ovary show invasive adenocarcinoma.  Differentiation varies with predominantly well to moderate differentiation and a minor poorly differentiated component.  The tumour is composed of tubular and cribriform glandular structures within a moderately cellular oedematous desmoplastic stroma.  In addition to small tubular and cribriform structures the tumour also contains a component of more cystically dilated glands a proportion of which are lined by very bland or mildly atypical simple or stratified columnar mucinous epithelium. Expansile nodular or intracystic papillary growth is not seen.  Some of the cystically dilated areas show higher grade nuclear atypia. Whilst the tumour mainly shows destructive stromal invasion with associated desmoplasia, some area including the cysts are associated with ovarian stroma in a pattern resembling an ovarian mucinous borderline neoplasm  with and without intracystic carcinoma .  The poorly differentiated component comprises minor foci (less than 5%) in which there is either single cell infiltration or signet ring-like differentiation (eg D8, D16, D18).  No associated extracellular mucin deposition to indicate pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  No microscopic surface mucin, or surface deposits are seen. Two small areas of surface disruption are noted.    Occasional glands contain necrotic luminal debris which are predominantly of inflammatory cells with some associated necrotic epithelial cells. Invasive adenocarcinoma involves the fallopian tube with invasion of the wall from the serosal surface (D18, D20) reaching the mucosa at the fimbrial end (D21) .  There is focal endometriosis close to the fallopian tube (D21). The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and no serous tubular carcinoma in-situ is seen.  No benign Brenner component is seen. The ovarian hilum is not identified.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.


E.  Sections of uterus show metastatic adenocarcinoma seenpredominantly surface deposits on the anterior surface (E4).  Adenocarcinoma is also present in the vicinity of the right cornua (E10) and close to the posterior peritoneal reflection (E12).  The carcinoma shows similar morphology to the pancreatic and ovarian disease.   There are also foci of endosalpingiosis (eg E5, E7) as well as endometriosis (E13).  The uterus shows a couple of fibroids (E14, E1) and is otherwise unremarkable. The endometrium is predominantly basal but appears inactive.  The ectocervix and and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.

F.  The right ovary is extensively sampled and the attached fallopian tube including fimbrial end entirely embedded and examined.  Sections of ovary confirm a surface serous low grade borderline tumour associated with psammomatous calcifications as well as multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows similar features to that seen in the left ovary and pancreas.  The deposits are seen on the surface of the ovary and also as a single expansile nodule. The expansile nodule shows areas in which the malignant glands are present with  ovarian stroma as well as areas with stromal  desmoplasia. The surface deposits which show similar cytomorphology are present amongst desmoplastic stroma.  The glands show a tubular and cribriform morphology with some poorly differentiated areas with single cell growth (eg F6).  No pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  Metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is also seen within the right ovarian hilum (F11).  Definite lymphovascular invasion is not identified.  Foci of endometriosis are also seen (F11).The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and is unremarkable and uninvolved.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the adenocarcinoma stains as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

In contrast to the adenocarcinoma the serous borderline tumour shows typical expression for PAX8, WT1, CK7, ER and PR. CK19 is also positive while CK20 and CDX2 are negative.

G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar morphology to that seen within the ovaries and pancreas. The carcinoma is composed of small tubular and cribriform glands within a desmoplastic stroma and is seen on the serosal surface associated with mesothelial cell reaction.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are seen both in the vicinity of tumour and separately.  Foci of endosalpingiosis are also seen (G5 and G6). One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stroma. The carcinoma appears well to moderately differentiated with well formed tubular or cribriform glands.  One small lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

I &amp; J.  Sections of fibroadipose tissue show a deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar features to that seen in the other sites.  The carcinoma is well to moderately differentiated.


COMMENT:
The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr W Vaneekelen who favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Erasmo comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Pancreatic core biopsy (frozen section):
-    Atypical mucinous epithelium which in this context is consistent with adenocarcinoma.

B.  Pancreatic biopsy (frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion (see comment).

C.  Right ovarian lesion (frozen section):
-    Low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Left ovary and fallopian tube (including frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma within ovary and fallopian tube (see comment).

E.  Uterus:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis and endometriosis.
-    Fibroids.

F.  Right ovary and fallopian tube:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma in ovary.
-    Ovarian low grade serous borderline tumour.
-    Uninvolved fallopian tube

G.  Omentum:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis.

H.  Peritoneal nodule:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

I.   Right side wall:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

J.   Nodule peritoneum:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The findings were discussed with Drs W Jecmenek &amp; W Lionetti and  Profs. W Provazek and W Wrye.

HISTORY:
Ca ovry.  Omentum.

MACROSCOPIC:
&quot;OMENTUM&quot;. Consists of multiple pieces of unorientated fibroadipose tissue and blood clot, 6-200mm in size and 200x210x50mm in aggregate.  On the fatty tissue, resembling omentum, there are milky white, thick areas, which are present on both the surface and within the fatty tissue.

(1-3 RS from the largest piece of fatty tissue; 4 sections from the second largest piece of tissue; 5 RS of a smaller piece of lobulated fatty tissue; 6 sections from a more fibromembraneous area). RS (M-6/LK/ank)

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr. L Sperow)
Sections show adipose tissue extensively infiltrated by a clear cell tumour.  The tumour has a predominantly papillary growth pattern, but also shows areas of tubular growth pattern.  There are scattered psammoma bodies present.  The papillary cores in some areas have a hyalinised appearance.  In some areas, eosinophilic material is seen within the tubular structures.  Individual tumour cells have abundant clear cytoplasm, and irregular nuclei with some nuclear membrane folding, and small nucleoli.  There is little or no nuclear stratification in most areas.  Mitotic figures are extremely sparse (less than 1 per 10 high power fields).  Immunohistochemical stains show that the tumour is positive for EMA, PAX8, Ber-EP4, CK7, and HBME-1.  It shows very weak variable focal positivity for p53, and very focal positivity for Napsin A.  It is negative for WT1, cytokeratin 20, calretinin, CEA, p16, AMACR, and D-240.
This case has been subject to intradepartmental consultation.  The appearances raise a differential diagnosis of clear cell carcinoma versus serous carcinoma.  The overall histologic appearance and immunohistochemical staining pattern favours clear cell carcinoma.  While the female genital tract is the most likely site of origin, clinical correlation is required as to likely primary site.
DIAGNOSIS:
OMENTUM:
- FAVOUR CLEAR CELL CARCINOMA.
- CLINICAL CORRELATION IS REQUIRED AS TO MOST LIKELY SITE OF ORIGIN (PLEASE SEE TEXT AND COMMENT ABOVE).

Comment:
Absence of staining for either MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSH-H), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair enzyme.

Positive staining of a carcinoma for MLH1,  PMS2,  MSH2  and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The antibodies used are not fully characterised for routine diagnostic use. Results may be affected by storage and fixation of specimens, and should be interpreted in conjunction with other investigation, including MSI testing where possible.
